<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>2<BR>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=center><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"><B>EXPLANATORY NOTE (I) 
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=center>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">On April 6, 
2016, Goldland Holdings, Co. (the &#147;registrant&#148;) changed its corporate 
name to Bravo Multinational Incorporated. &nbsp;On March 22, 2016, the board of 
directors of the registrant, pursuant to Section 242 of the Delaware General 
Corporation Law, determined it was in the best interests of the registrant that 
the name of the registrant should be changed to Bravo Multinational 
Incorporated, with such change of name to be effective upon compliance with all 
regulatory requirements mandated by FINRA. &nbsp;Further, as a result of the 
change of the registrant&#146;s name and upon satisfaction of all regulatory 
requirements, the trading symbol for the shares of the registrant&#146;s common 
stock should be changed to &#147;BRVO,&#148; and the registrant&#146;s CUSIP 
identifier be changed to a newly issued number. &nbsp;FINRA granted its approval
of the change of the registrant&#146;s name on April 6, 2015. &nbsp;As a result 
of the change of name of the registrant, the registrant&#146;s trading symbol 
was changed to &#147;BRVO&#148; and the CUSIP identifier was changed to 
10568F109.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The registrant 
filed a Form 8-K with the SEC on April 7, 2016, announcing the change of name, 
trading symbol, and CUSIP identifier.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>SPECIAL NOTE 
REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In light of the 
risks and uncertainties inherent in all projected operational matters, the 
inclusion of forward-looking statements in this Form 10-K, should not be 
regarded as a representation by us or any other person that any of our 
objectives or plans will be achieved or that any of our operating expectations 
will be realized. &nbsp;Our revenues and results of operations are difficult to 
forecast and could differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking
statements contained in this Form 10-K, as a result of certain risks and 
uncertainties including, but not limited to, our business reliance on third 
parties to provide us with technology, our ability to integrate and manage 
acquired technology, assets, companies and personnel, changes in market 
condition, the volatile and intensely competitive environment in the business 
sectors in which we operate, rapid technological change, and our dependence on 
key and scarce employees in a competitive market for skilled personnel. 
&nbsp;These factors should not be considered exhaustive; we undertake no 
obligation to release publicly the results of any future revisions we may make 
to forward-looking statements to reflect events or circumstances after the date 
hereof or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events.</P>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
<p align="center">&nbsp;</p>
<p align="center">3</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>PART I</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Except for 
historical information, this report contains forward-looking statements within 
the meaning of Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended 
(the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;). &nbsp;Such forward-looking statements involve 
risks and uncertainties, including, among other things, statements regarding our
business strategy, future revenues and anticipated costs and expenses. 
&nbsp;Such forward-looking statements include, among others, those statements 
including the words &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;anticipates,&#148; 
&#147;intends,&#148; &#147;believes&#148; and similar language. &nbsp;Our actual
results may differ significantly from those projected in the forward-looking 
statements. &nbsp;Factors that might cause or contribute to such differences 
include, but are not limited to, those discussed in the section &#147;Item 7. 
&nbsp;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and 
Results of Operations.&#148; &nbsp;You are cautioned not to place undue reliance
on the forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date of this 
report. &nbsp;We undertake no obligation to publicly release any revisions to 
the forward-looking statements or reflect events or circumstances taking place 
after the date of this document.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<p style="margin-bottom: 10pt"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Item 
1.</B></FONT><B>Business.</B></p>
<p style="margin-bottom: 10pt">&nbsp;</p>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman"><B>Company Overview</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We were 
originally formed as Montrose Ventures, Inc. in the State of Delaware on May 25,
1989. &nbsp;On April 23, 1996, our name was changed to Java Group, Inc., which 
tried and failed to start a chain of coffee bars. &nbsp;On September 1, 2004, 
our name was changed to Consolidated General Corp., which tried to buy tier 2 
and 3 professional sports teams, including the Vancouver Ravens lacrosse team 
and the San Diego Soccers soccer team. &nbsp;On August 7, 2007, our name was 
changed to Goldcorp Holdings Co. &nbsp;On October 15, 2010, our name was changed
to GoldLand Holdings Co. &nbsp;On April 6, 2016, our name was changed to Bravo 
Multinational Incorporated.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always"><B>Former Business</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Over the years, 
and prior to our entry into the business of the leasing of gaming equipment 
described below, we have been engaged in the business of leasing mining claims. 
&nbsp;On September 14, 2007, we acquired an interest in 174.82 acres of land on 
War Eagle Mountain in Idaho from Bisell Investments Inc. and New Vision 
Financial Ltd., two of our then major stockholders, for a total of 90,000,000 
shares of our common stock. &nbsp;We acquired a 100% interest in 103 acres, and 
a 29.167% interest in 76.63 acres, respectively. &nbsp;We also leased five 
placer claims on War Eagle Mountain from the U.S. Bureau of Land Management (the
&#147;BLM&#148;), each of which covered approximately 20 acres, or approximately
100 acres in total. &nbsp;Subsequently, as a result of a survey we allowed our 
original BLM claims to lapse, and reapplied for new lode claims that are better 
oriented in the direction of the three veins in the mountain. &nbsp;As a result,
we own 14 unpatented lode claims covering 262.85 acres and 76.63 acres within 
seven patented claims with a 29.167% ownership interest. &nbsp;We may look to 
expand on our mining claims holdings in the future.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">For a complete 
discussion of the mining activities on our mining claims conducted by other 
parties, please see our previous Form 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and 8-Ks filed with the SEC.
&nbsp;However it should be noted that at no time was Goldland Holdings a mining 
operator. &nbsp;As descried above, Goldland Holdings owns and or maintains 
mining claims which are leased to a third party. Since the mining operations of
our lessee no longer have any relevance to our new business of the leasing of 
gaming equipment, we will only include financial information relating to 
revenues, expenses, and results of operations and other relevant information 
with respect to the former mining activities of the lessee of our mining 
properties.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Current Business</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We are currently
engaged in the business of the leasing of gaming equipment. &nbsp;On September 
19, 2013, Universal Equipment SAS, Inc., our wholly-owned subsidiary, entered 
into an asset purchase agreement to acquire certain gaming equipment from 
Universal Entertainment SAS, Ltd., a corporation formed under the laws of the 
Country of Colombia, for 17,450,535 shares of our common stock (post reverse-
split on March 6, 2014). &nbsp;The closing occurred on March 6, 2014. &nbsp;The 
gaming equipment includes approximately 67 video poker and slot machines; eight 
blackjack and miscellaneous game tables, and related furniture and equipment; 
roulette table and related furniture and equipment; bingo equipment and 
furniture; casino chips, bill acceptors, coin counter and related equipment, and
miscellaneous office equipment, like chairs and tables.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Upon closing of 
the acquisition of the gaming equipment, through our wholly owned subsidiary 
Universal Entertainment SAS, Inc. on March 6, 2014, we leased the gaming 
equipment to Vomblom &amp; Pomare S.A., a company formed under the laws of the 
Country of Colombia, and controlled by Claudia Fuentes Robales, pursuant to a 
lease agreement which provided for lease payments of $700,000 per year, payable 
in the amount of $58,333 per month, with a term of five years with one five year
renewal option. &nbsp;The gaming equipment was to be used primarily in the 
operation of a casino that is owned and operated by the lessee on San Andres 
Isla, Colombia. &nbsp;However, some of the gaming equipment, such as video poker
and slot machines, could have been placed in retail locations under agreements 
with the retail merchants to divide winnings from the machines.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The above 
referred to lease agreement was cancelled by Universal Equipment SAS, Inc., on 
June 18, 2015, due to non-payment of the lease payments. &nbsp;We are now 
assessing new opportunities for the leasing of the gaming equipment.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Risks Related to Our Gaming 
Equipment Operations</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We are affected 
by the risks faced by foreign casino owners who we expect will be our future 
customers. &nbsp;Our prospective gaming machine customers are engaged in 
economically sensitive and competitive businesses. &nbsp;As a result, we will be
indirectly affected by all the risks facing foreign casino owners, which are 
beyond our control. &nbsp;Our results of operations will depend, in part, on the
financial strength of our customers and our customers&#146; ability to compete 
effectively in the marketplace and manage their risks. &nbsp;Many of these risks
are discussed below.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>4</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; page-break-
before:always"><I>Reductions in Consumer and Corporate Spending.</I> 
&nbsp;Consumer demand for hotel/casino resorts, trade shows and conventions, and
for luxury amenities is particularly sensitive to downturns in the economy and 
the corresponding impact on discretionary spending on leisure activities. 
&nbsp;Changes in discretionary consumer spending or corporate spending on 
conventions and business travel could be driven by many factors, such as 
perceived or actual general economic conditions; any further weaknesses in the 
job or housing market; additional credit market disruptions; high energy, fuel 
and food costs; the increased cost of travel; the potential for bank failures; 
perceived or actual disposable consumer income and wealth; fears of recession 
and changes in consumer confidence in the economy; or fears of war and future 
acts of terrorism. &nbsp;These factors could reduce consumer and corporate 
demand for the luxury amenities and leisure activities of our customers, thus
imposing additional limits on pricing and harming our operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Regulations 
Affecting Casinos.</I> &nbsp;Casinos are subject to extensive regulation and the
cost of compliance or failure to comply with such regulations may have an 
adverse effect on their business, financial condition, results of operations or 
cash flows. &nbsp;Casinos are required to obtain and maintain licenses from the 
jurisdictions in which they operate, and are subject to extensive background 
investigations and suitability standards. &nbsp;In some cases, a casino license 
may be subject to revocation at any time by government officials. &nbsp;There 
can be no assurance that our prospective casino customers will be able to obtain
new licenses or renew any of their existing licenses, or that if such licenses 
are obtained, that such licenses will not be conditioned, suspended or revoked. 
&nbsp;The loss, denial or non-renewal of any of their licenses could have a 
material adverse effect on their and our business, financial condition, results 
of operations or cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Casinos are 
Subject to Anti-Money Laundering Laws.</I> &nbsp;Our prospective casino 
customers will deal with significant amounts of cash in their operations and 
will be subject to various reporting and anti-money laundering regulations. 
&nbsp;Any violation of anti-money laundering laws or regulations, or any 
accusations of money laundering or regulatory investigations into possible money
laundering activities, by any of the properties, employees, or customers of our 
prospective casino customers could have a material adverse effect on their 
financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Travel 
Concerns.</I> &nbsp;Casinos are sensitive to the willingness of customers to 
travel. &nbsp;Only a small amount of our potential casino customers&#146; 
business will be generated by local residents. &nbsp;Most of their customers 
travel to reach their properties. &nbsp;Acts of terrorism may severely disrupt 
domestic and international travel, which would result in a decrease in customer 
visits to our potential customers&#146; properties. &nbsp;Regional conflicts 
could have a similar effect on domestic and international travel. &nbsp;We 
cannot predict the extent to which disruptions in air or other forms of travel 
as a result of any further terrorist act, outbreak of hostilities or escalation 
of war would have on our potential casino customers&#146; financial condition, 
results of operations or cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Win 
Rates.</I> &nbsp;Win rates for casinos gaming operations depend on a variety of 
factors, some beyond their control. &nbsp;Consequently, the winnings of a 
casino&#146;s gaming customers could exceed the casino&#146;s winnings. 
&nbsp;The gaming industry is characterized by an element of chance. &nbsp;In 
addition to the element of chance, win rates are also affected by other factors,
including the players&#146; skill and experience, the mix of games played, the 
financial resources of the players, the spread of table limits, the volume of 
bets placed and the amount of time played. &nbsp;Our potential casino 
customers&#146; gaming profits are expected to mainly derive from the difference
between their casino winnings and the casino winnings of their gaming customers.
&nbsp;Since there is an inherent element of chance in the gaming industry, our 
potential casino customers will not have full control over their winnings or the
winnings of their gaming customers. &nbsp;If the winnings of their gaming 
customers exceed their winnings, they may record a loss from gaming operations, 
which could have a material adverse effect on their (and our) business, 
financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Fraud and 
Cheating Issues.</I> &nbsp;Casinos face the risk of fraud and cheating. 
&nbsp;Our potential casino customers&#146; will most likely face attempts by 
some of their customers to commit fraud or cheat in order to increase winnings. 
&nbsp;Acts of fraud or cheating could involve the use of counterfeit chips or 
other tactics, possibly in collusion with a casino&#146;s employees. 
&nbsp;Internal acts of cheating could also be conducted by employees through 
collusion with dealers, surveillance staff, floor managers or other casino or 
gaming area staff. &nbsp;Failure to discover such acts or schemes in a timely 
manner could result in losses to our potential casino customers gaming 
operations. &nbsp;In addition, negative publicity related to such schemes could
have an adverse effect on our potential casino customers&#146; reputations, 
likely causing a material adverse effect on their (and our) business, financial 
condition, results of operations and cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>5</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Limited 
Markets.</I> &nbsp;Because we expect to be dependent primarily upon gaming 
operations in two markets,
&nbsp;
Central and South America, initially in Columbia, for all of our cash flow, we 
will be subject to greater risks than competitors with more casino customers or 
which operate in more markets. &nbsp;We do not currently have any casino 
equipment leasing operations. &nbsp;As a result, we do not have any current cash
flow from operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Given that our 
operations are initially expected to be conducted only in Columbia, we will be 
subject to greater degrees of risk than competitors with more operating 
properties or that operate in more markets. &nbsp;The risks to which we will 
have a greater degree of exposure will include the following:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Local economic and competitive conditions;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Inaccessibility due to inclement weather, road 
construction or closure of primary access routes;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Decline in air passenger traffic due to higher ticket 
costs or fears concerning air travel;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Changes in local and state governmental laws and 
regulations, including gaming laws and regulations;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Natural or man-made disasters, or outbreaks of infectious
diseases;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A decline in the number of visitors to San Andres Isla, 
Columbia, where we expect to commence operations.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Tax Laws and 
Regulations.</I> &nbsp;Changes in tax laws and regulations could impact our 
financial condition and results of operations. &nbsp;We will be subject to 
taxation and regulation by various governmental agencies, primarily in Columbia,
and other Central and South American countries, and the United States (federal, 
state and local levels). &nbsp;From time to time, U.S. federal, state, local and
foreign governments make substantive changes to tax rules and the application of
these rules, which could result in higher taxes than would be incurred under 
existing tax law or interpretation. &nbsp;In particular, governmental agencies 
may make changes that could reduce the profits that we can effectively realize
from our non-U.S. operations. &nbsp;Like most U.S. companies, our effective 
income tax rate will reflect the fact that income earned and reinvested outside 
the U.S. is taxed at local rates, which are often lower than U.S. tax rates. 
&nbsp;If changes in tax laws and regulations were to significantly increase the 
tax rates on non-U.S. income, these changes could increase our income tax 
expense and liability, and therefore, could have an adverse effect on our 
effective income tax rate, financial condition and results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Financial 
Markets Financing Concerns.</I> &nbsp;Disruptions in the financial markets could
have an adverse effect on our ability to raise additional financing. &nbsp;To 
expand our casino equipment leasing business, we will need to finance the 
purchase of new casino equipment. &nbsp;We currently do not have any 
arrangements to obtain debt or equity capital to finance new equipment 
purchases, and if we do not obtain such capital we may be unable to expand our 
anticipated operations. &nbsp;Severe disruptions in the commercial credit 
markets in the recent past have resulted in a tightening of credit markets 
worldwide. &nbsp;Liquidity in the global credit markets was severely contracted 
by these market disruptions, making it difficult and costly to obtain new lines 
of credit or to refinance existing debt. &nbsp;The effect of these disruptions 
was widespread and difficult to quantify. &nbsp;While economic conditions have 
recently improved, that trend may not continue and the extent of the current 
economic improvement is unknown. &nbsp;Any future disruptions in the commercial 
credit markets may impact liquidity in the global credit market as greatly, or 
even more, than in recent years.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our business and
financing plan may be dependent upon completion of future financings. &nbsp;If 
the credit environment worsens, it may be difficult to obtain any additional 
financing on acceptable terms, which could have an adverse effect on our ability
to complete our planned projects, and as a consequence, our results of 
operations and business plans. &nbsp;Should general economic conditions not 
improve, if we are unable to obtain sufficient funding or applicable government 
approvals such that completion of planned projects is not probable, or should 
management decide to abandon certain projects, all or a portion of our 
investment to date in our planned projects could be lost and would result in an 
impairment charge.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>6<BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Currency 
Risks.</I> &nbsp;Our potential casino customers will be subject to currency 
risks. &nbsp;Our gaming equipment lease provides for lease payments in U.S. 
dollars, while our lessees will conduct business in the currency of the country 
where the lessee is located. &nbsp;Accordingly, our lessees&#146; ability to 
make lease payments will be subject to our lessees&#146; ability to convert the 
foreign currency into U.S. dollars. &nbsp;As a result, our lessee&#146;s ability
to make lease payments will be subject to fluctuations in the exchange rate of 
the applicable foreign currency against the U.S. dollar, as well as local laws 
and regulations which may limit or impair a foreign person or entity&#146;s 
ability to convert the subject foreign currency to U.S. dollars.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Our Legal 
Rights and Remedies are Uncertain in the Event of a Default by a Lessee.</I> 
&nbsp;In the event we are required to take any legal action under a lease of our
casino equipment, such as to repossess our equipment, we would be required to do
so in the courts, and under the laws, of the country where the equipment is 
located. &nbsp;The legal systems of foreign countries may not allow for the 
repossession of equipment as quickly and as cost-effectively as in the U.S., 
with the result that we may face greater delays and expenses in exercising any 
rights under our leases. &nbsp;Consequently, losses due to a default by a lessee
may be greater than otherwise would be the case.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Conflict of 
Interest.</I> &nbsp;Paul Parliament, our chairman, president, chief executive
officer, and director, has an indirect conflict of interest inasmuch as he has a
private business relationship with Game Touch Technologies Inc., a company 
controlled by one of our consultants and current major stockholder, Julios 
Kosta, from whom Mr. Parliament purchased gaming equipment. &nbsp;Game Touch has
no business relationship with Goldland Holdings.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Competition</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">To the extent we
expand leasing our casino equipment to more than one operator we will face 
competition from casino equipment suppliers, leasing affiliates of casino 
equipment suppliers, and independent leasing companies. &nbsp;Most of our 
potential competitors have far greater resources than we have and have far 
greater experience in the casino industry than we possess.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Markets and Major 
Customers</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">While all 
casinos need casino equipment, we define our market as casinos in Central and 
South America, which we believe is an underserved market. &nbsp;Currently, we do
not have any customers.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Seasonality of Business</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Because we 
intend to lease our gaming equipment pursuant to master leases, we do not expect
that our revenues and earnings from our casino equipment line of business will 
be affected by seasonal factors. &nbsp;However, casino lessees may be located in
resort or vacation locations, which make their operations subject to seasonal 
fluctuations, which may affect our cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Regulations</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The gaming 
industry is subject to extensive governmental regulation by federal, state and 
local governments, as well as tribal officials or organizations and foreign 
governments. &nbsp;While the regulatory requirements vary by jurisdiction, most 
require:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Licenses and/or permits;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Findings of suitability for the operator, as well as 
individual officers, directors, major shareholders, and key 
employees;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Documentation of qualifications, including evidence of 
financial stability; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>7</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol; page-break-before:always"><FONT 
FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Other required approvals for manufacturers or 
distributors of gaming equipment and services, including but not limited to new 
product approvals.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Gaming laws and 
regulations serve to protect the public and ensure that gaming related activity 
is conducted honestly, competitively, and free of corruption. &nbsp;Regulatory 
oversight additionally ensures that the local authorities receive the 
appropriate amount of gaming tax revenues.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Certain
regulators not only govern the activities within their jurisdiction, but also 
monitor activities in other jurisdictions to ensure that the operator complies 
with local standards on a worldwide basis. &nbsp;For example, the State of 
Nevada requires that its licensees maintain Nevada standards for all operations 
worldwide. &nbsp;Violations of laws in one jurisdiction could result in 
disciplinary action in other jurisdictions. &nbsp;We will require that our 
potential lessees maintain any required licenses to use our equipment in their 
facilities.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Since we do not 
manufacture gaming equipment, we are not subject to license requirements 
applicable to gaming equipment manufacturers.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:4.15pt"><B>Patents and Intellectual 
Property</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We do not have 
any patents or trademarks.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:4.15pt"><B>Impact of Inflation</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We are affected 
by inflation along with the rest of the economy. &nbsp;Specifically, our costs 
to operate a company whose shares are publicly traded.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Adequacy of Working 
Capital</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We will apply 
great efforts to raise though equity or debt offerings what we feel is 
sufficient working capital for our intended business plan by various means. 
&nbsp;If we are not able to raise additional capital, we would not be able to 
continue operations and our business may fail.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Our Financial Results May Be 
Affected by Factors Outside of Our Control</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our future 
operating results may vary significantly from quarter to quarter due to a 
variety of factors, many of which are outside our control. &nbsp;Our anticipated
expense levels are based, in part, on our estimates of future revenues and may 
vary from projections. &nbsp;We may be unable to adjust spending rapidly enough 
to compensate for any unexpected revenues shortfall. &nbsp;Accordingly, any 
significant shortfall in revenues in relation to our planned expenditures would 
materially and adversely affect our business, operating results, and financial 
condition. &nbsp;Further, we believe that period-to-period comparisons of our 
operating results are not necessarily a meaningful indication of future 
performance.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Key Personnel</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our future 
financial success depends to a large degree upon the personal efforts of our key
personnel, Paul Parliament, our chairman, president, chief executive officer, 
and director, Martin Wolfe, our chief financial officer, principal accounting 
officer, and director, Douglas Brooks, our vice president and director, and 
Richard Kaiser, our secretary and corporate governance officer, all of whom will
play a major role in securing the services of those persons who can develop our 
business strategy upon receipt of sufficient funds to pay for such services 
either from success through receipt of funds from earnings, borrowing or sales 
of our securities. &nbsp;While we intend to employ additional management and 
marketing personnel in order to minimize the critical dependency upon any one 
person, there can be no assurance that we will be successful in attracting and 
retaining the persons needed. &nbsp;We have employment agreements with each of 
Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, and Kaiser, and consulting agreements with 
FMW Media Works Inc., Vincent Caruso, Stephen Simon, and Delaney Equity Group, 
LLC. &nbsp;See &#147;&#147;Item 7. &nbsp;Management&#146;s Discussion and 
Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations - Consulting 
Agreements.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>8</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always"><B>Adequacy of Working Capital</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We hope to 
generate sufficient capital to fund our business plan through investments in our
securities, revenues from operations, or borrowings. &nbsp;See Item 7. 
&nbsp;&#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and
Results of Operations &#150; Financing Activities.&#148; &nbsp;If we are not 
able to raise additional capital as described above, we would not be able to 
continue and our business would fail. &nbsp;As of the date of this report, we do
not have any commitments for financing.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:4.15pt"><B>Employees</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As of the date 
of this report, we have four employees, Paul Parliament, our chairman, 
president, chief executive officer, and director, Martin Wolfe, our chief 
financial officer, principal accounting officer, and director, Douglas Brooks, 
our vice president and director, and Richard Kaiser, our secretary and corporate
governance officer. &nbsp;We currently anticipate that we will not hire any 
additional employees over the next 12 months. &nbsp;As our operations expand, we
will need to employ additional personnel. &nbsp;We do not feel that we would 
have any difficulty in locating needed help.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">From time-to-
time, we anticipate that we will use the services of independent contractors and
consultants to support our business development and who have experience in the 
leasing of gaming equipment in Central and South America, such as Julios Kosta, 
one of our major stockholders. &nbsp;We believe our future success depends in 
large part upon the continued service of our senior management personnel and our
ability to attract and retain highly qualified managerial personnel.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Transfer Agent</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our transfer 
agent is Transfer Online Inc. whose address is 512 SE Salmon Street, Portland, 
Oregon 97214, and telephone number (503) 227-2950.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Company Contact 
Information</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our principal 
executive offices are located at 590 York Road, Unit 3, Niagara On The Lake, 
Ontario, CANADA L0S 1J0, telephone (716) 803-0621. &nbsp;Our Internet website is
currently under construction. &nbsp;The information to be contained in our 
Internet website shall not constitute part of this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<p style="margin-bottom: 10pt"><B>Item 1A. </B><B>Risk Factors.</B></p>
<p style="margin-bottom: 10pt">&nbsp;</p>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B><I>Risks Relating to Our Business</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Inasmuch as 
mining operations by our lessee have been terminated on our mining leases, the 
following discussion of Risk Factors relates only to our gaming equipment 
leasing business going forward. &nbsp;However, we do still own 14 unpatented 
lode claims covering 262.85 acres and 76.63 acres within seven patented claims 
with a 29.167% ownership interest. &nbsp;We will maintain their status for the 
foreseeable future.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Except as 
otherwise indicated by the context, references in this report to &#147;we,&#148;
&#147;us,&#148; &#147;our,&#148; the &#147;company&#148; or &#147;Goldland 
Holdings&#148; are to the business of Bravo Multinational Incorporated and our 
wholly-owned subsidiaries, Universal Entertainment SAS, Inc. and Bravo Gaming 
Corporation.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We are a holding company of 
several affiliated companies, with limited operating businesses.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Goldland 
Holdings has no recent operating history upon which you can evaluate our gaming 
equipment business and prospects. &nbsp;You must consider the risks and 
uncertainties frequently encountered by companies whose businesses deal with 
gaming equipment leasing. &nbsp;If we are unsuccessful in addressing these risks
and uncertainties, our business, results of operations and financial condition 
will be materially and adversely affected.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>9</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always"><B>Our 
auditors have stated we may not be able to stay in business.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our auditors 
have issued a going concern opinion, which means that there is substantial doubt
that we can continue as an ongoing business for the next 12 months. &nbsp;Unless
we can raise additional capital, we may not be able to achieve our objectives 
and may have to suspend or cease operations. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 7. 
&nbsp;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and 
Results of Operations.&#148; &nbsp;In the future, we may raise additional 
capital though equity or debt offerings.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Our future revenues are 
unpredictable and our quarterly operating results may fluctuate 
significantly.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Although 
Goldland Holdings was incorporated in 1989, we have had only a limited operating
history, and have no recent revenues. &nbsp;We cannot forecast with any degree 
of certainty whether our proposed gaming equipment leasing business will ever 
generate revenue or the amount of revenue to be generated. &nbsp;In addition, we
cannot predict the consistency of our quarterly operating results.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We estimate that
we will need at least $300,000 to fund our operations over the next 12 months, 
in addition to repaying or refinancing promissory notes, which are due within 12
to 24 months. &nbsp;The outstanding liabilities include $158, 498 due to 
directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We may have difficulty in 
attracting and retaining management and outside independent members to our board
of directors as a result of their concerns relating to their increased personal 
exposure to lawsuits and stockholder claims by virtue of holding these positions
in a publicly held company.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our shares of 
common stock are publicly traded on the &#147;OTCPK&#148; operated by OTC 
Markets Group, Inc. discussed below. &nbsp;The directors and management of 
publicly traded corporations are increasingly concerned with the extent of their
personal exposure to lawsuits and stockholder claims, as well as governmental 
and creditor claims which may be made against them, particularly in view of 
recent changes in securities laws imposing additional duties, obligations and 
liabilities on management and directors. &nbsp;Due to these perceived risks, 
directors and management are also becoming increasingly concerned with the 
availability of directors and officers&#146; liability insurance to pay on a 
timely basis the costs incurred in defending such claims. &nbsp;We currently do 
not carry directors and officers&#146; liability insurance. &nbsp;Directors and 
officers&#146; liability insurance has recently become much more expensive and 
difficult to obtain. &nbsp;If we are unable to provide directors and 
officers&#146; liability insurance at affordable rates or at all, it may become 
increasingly more difficult to attract and retain qualified outside directors to
serve on our board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Compliance with changing 
regulation of financial reporting, corporate governance and public disclosure 
may result in additional expenses and diversion of management time and attention
from operational activities.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Compliance with 
changing laws, regulations and standards relating to financial reporting, 
corporate governance and public disclosure, including new accounting standards, 
SEC regulations, and FINRA (Financial Industry Regulatory Authority) rules, are 
time consuming and expensive. &nbsp;We have spent substantial amounts of 
management time and have incurred substantial legal and accounting expense in 
the past in complying with these federal securities laws. &nbsp;Complying with 
these laws and regulations also creates uncertainty for companies such as ours. 
&nbsp;These laws, regulations and standards are subject to varying
interpretations, in many cases due to their lack of specificity. &nbsp;As a 
result, their application in practice may evolve over time as new guidance is 
provided by regulatory and governing bodies, which could result in continuing 
uncertainty regarding compliance matters and higher costs necessitated by 
ongoing revisions to disclosure and governance practices.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Any claims or threats of 
litigation could distract us from business operations and strategic planning, 
and costs of litigation or settlement could adversely affect our financial 
condition or results of operations.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Any claims made 
or litigation commenced against us, or our officers or directors, may distract 
our board of directors, management, or other key employees from business 
operations and strategic planning. &nbsp;There may also be an increase versus 
prior periods in potential claims or litigation relative to our operational 
growth. &nbsp;Claims resolution frequently entails a cost/benefit analysis, 
which would include consideration of the potential risks, expenses and impact to
business operations. &nbsp;We may determine to litigate or settle such claims 
(including threatened claims) even if we believe those claims have little or no 
merit. &nbsp;The cost of litigation or settlements could adversely affect our 
financial condition or our results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>10</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We have a very small management
team and the loss of any member of this team may prevent us from implementing 
our business plan in a timely manner; our management has substantial outside 
business interests.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We have four 
executive officers and a limited number of additional consultants. &nbsp;Our 
success depends largely upon the continued services of Paul Parliament, our 
chairman, president, chief executive officer, and director, Martin Wolfe, our 
chief financial officer, principal accounting officer, and director, Douglas 
Brooks, our vice president and director, and Richard Kaiser, our secretary and 
corporate governance officer. &nbsp;We need additional executive personnel in 
order to fulfill our business plan and satisfy our reporting obligations as a 
public company in a timely fashion. &nbsp;We do not maintain key person life 
insurance policies on the lives of any of our officers. &nbsp;The loss of any of
our officers could seriously harm our business, financial condition and results 
of operations. &nbsp;In such an event, we may not be able to recruit personnel 
to replace our officers in a timely manner, or at all, on acceptable terms.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Furthermore, the
employment agreements with our executive officers permit them to have outside 
business interests, such that they are not required to devote 100% of their 
working time to our business. &nbsp;Mr. Parliament estimates that he spends 
about 80% of his working time on activities related to the activities of Bravo 
Multinational Incorporated . &nbsp;Mr. Wolfe estimates that he spends about 60% 
of his working time on our activities. &nbsp;Mr. Brooks estimates that he spends
about 60% of his working time on activities of Bravo Multinational 
Incorporated . &nbsp;Mr. Kaiser estimates that he spends about 60% of his 
working time on activities of Bravo Multinational Incorporated . &nbsp;The fact 
that Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, and Kaiser have outside business 
interests could lessen their focus on our business.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We have substantial commitments
that may require that we raise capital.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As of December 
31, 2015, we had current assets of $441,952 current liabilities of 
$278,898Included in current assets are prepaid expenses related to a marking 
agreement capital deficit of $237,914. &nbsp;A substantial part of our current 
liabilities consist of debts that we only have to pay if funds are available, 
such as amounts due related parties of $6,328. &nbsp;However, we have $168,262 
of accounts payable to third parties. &nbsp;Our officers also have agreed to
receive a portion their salaries in the form of shares of our common stock. 
&nbsp;If our officers do not agree to receive our stock in payment of their 
salaries, and we are unable to make payments in cash, we will have to raise 
capital in order to pay our liabilities, which we expect would be dilutive to 
existing stockholders.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>The continuing uncertainty in 
national and global economic conditions could negatively affect our business, 
results of operations and financial condition.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The recent 
financial crisis affecting the banking system and financial markets and the 
continuing uncertainty in national and global economic conditions resulted in a 
tightening in the credit markets, a low level of liquidity in many financial 
markets and extreme volatility in credit, equity and fixed income markets. 
&nbsp;It is difficult to estimate the exact impact of the economic crisis on our
business. &nbsp;There could still be a number of unforeseen or unidentified 
follow-on effects from these economic developments on our business and our 
potential casino customers. &nbsp;National economic risks that we have 
considered in our planning processes in the past 12 months include risks 
associated with the inability or unwillingness of banks to fund draws on 
revolving credit facilities, failure of our potential customers to pay us on a 
timely basis or at all, and delays in business and litigation-related 
expenditures by our potential customers. &nbsp;If the global economy or the U.S.
economy remains uncertain or weakens further, the consequences could have an 
adverse effect on our business, operating results and financial condition.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B><I>Risks Relating to Our Mining
Properties</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As we discussed 
above, although we still own our mining properties, we do not have a lessee 
currently conducting operations. &nbsp;However, there are still some risks 
associated with our mining properties, including those risks described below. 
&nbsp;For a complete discussion of mining operations conducted by our lessee, 
please see our previous Form 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and 8-Ks filed with the SEC.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>11</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We have minimal revenue to date
from our mining properties, which may negatively impact our ability to achieve 
our business objectives.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Since acquiring 
our mining properties in September 2007, we have experienced losses from our 
operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>The properties in which we have
an interest do not have any known reserves.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">None of the 
properties in which we have an interest have any known reserves. &nbsp;To date, 
we have engaged in only limited preliminary exploration activities on the 
properties. Accordingly, we do not have sufficient information upon which to 
assess the ultimate success of our exploration efforts.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Silver Falcon, our lessee, has 
a limited operating history as a mining company, which may hinder Silver 
Falcon&#146;s ability to make lease and royalty payments to us.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We do not have 
any operating history as a mining company upon which to base an evaluation of 
our current business and future prospects. &nbsp;We have only owned mining 
properties since our acquisition of properties on War Eagle Mountain in 
September 2007. &nbsp;Silver Falcon has only a limited operating history as a 
mining company. &nbsp;Silver Falcon first entered the mining industry when it 
leased our properties on War Eagle Mountain in October 2007. &nbsp;We do not 
have an established history of locating and developing properties that have 
mining reserves. &nbsp;Currently, Silver Falcon is in default with respect to
our lease and is not conducting any mining operations on our mining 
properties.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><B>There are 
uncertainties as to title matters in the mining industry. &nbsp;Any defects in 
such title could cause us to lose our rights in mineral properties and 
jeopardize our business operations.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our mineral 
properties consist of private mineral rights, leases covering private lands, 
leases of patented mining claims and unpatented mining claims. Many of our 
mining properties in the United States are unpatented mining claims located on 
lands administered by the U.S. Bureau of Land Management (&#147;BLM&#148;), 
Idaho State Office to which we have only possessory title. &nbsp;Because title 
to unpatented mining claims is subject to inherent uncertainties, it is 
difficult to determine conclusively ownership of such claims. &nbsp;These 
uncertainties relate to such things as sufficiency of mineral discovery, proper 
location and posting and marking of boundaries, and possible conflicts with 
other claims not determinable from descriptions of record. &nbsp;We believe a 
substantial portion of all mineral exploration, development and mining in the 
United States now occurs on unpatented mining claims, and this uncertainty is 
inherent in the mining industry.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The present 
status of our unpatented mining claims located on public lands allows us the 
right to mine and remove valuable minerals, such as precious and base metals, 
from the claims conditioned upon applicable environmental reviews and permitting
programs. &nbsp;We also are generally allowed to use the surface of the land 
solely for purposes related to mining and processing the mineral-bearing ores. 
&nbsp;However, legal ownership of the land remains with the United States. 
&nbsp;We remain at risk that the mining claims may be forfeited either to the 
United States or to rival private claimants due to failure to comply with 
statutory requirements. &nbsp;Prior to 1994, a mining claim locator who was able
to prove the discovery of valuable, locatable minerals on a mining claim, and to
meet all other applicable federal and state requirements and procedures 
pertaining to the location and maintenance of federal unpatented mining claims, 
had the right to prosecute a patent application to secure fee title to the 
mining claim from the Federal government. &nbsp;The right to pursue a patent, 
however, has been subject to a moratorium since October 1994, through federal 
legislation restricting the BLM from accepting any new mineral patent 
applications. &nbsp;If we do not obtain fee title to our unpatented mining 
claims, we can provide no assurance that we will be able to obtain compensation 
in connection with the forfeiture of such claims.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">There may be 
challenges to title to the mineral properties in which we hold a material 
interest. &nbsp;If there are title defects with respect to any properties, we 
might be required to compensate other persons or perhaps reduce our interest in 
the affected property. &nbsp;Also, in any such case, the investigation and 
resolution of title issues would divert our management&#146;s time from ongoing 
production, exploration and development programs.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>12</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=justify><B>We are required to share our profits derived from properties in
which we do not own 100% fee title.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We only own a 
29.167% undivided interest in 76.63 acres of land on War Eagle Mountain. 
&nbsp;Under Idaho law, we are required to pay the other joint tenant owners of 
the land their pro rata share of any net revenues we derive from minerals 
extracted from their property, less operating costs we incur. &nbsp;We do not 
have any formal agreement with the majority owners of the 76.63 acres of land on
War Eagle Mountain regarding the allocation of revenues between 76.63 acres in 
which they have an interest and the other acreage we own or lease on War Eagle 
Mountain, or the determination and allocation of costs properly chargeable
against revenues allocated to their interests. &nbsp;Accordingly, there is a 
possibility that we may get into disputes with the majority owners of the 76.63 
acres of land on War Eagle Mountain, which could adversely affect our 
profitability.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B><I>Risks Relating to Our 
Stock</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman 
Bold"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Voting control of our shares is 
possessed by our management team. &nbsp;Additionally, this concentration of 
ownership could discourage or prevent a potential takeover of Goldland Holdings 
that might otherwise result in a stockholder receiving a premium over the market
price for his shares.</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Paul Parliament, our chairman, president, chief executive
officer, and director, Martin Wolfe, our chief financial officer, principal 
accounting officer, and director, Douglas Brooks, our vice president and 
director, and Richard Kaiser, our secretary and corporate governance officer, 
the management team of Bravo Multinational , and its subsidiaries, own 
approximately 13.78% of the outstanding shares of our common stock. &nbsp;In 
addition, Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, and Kaiser own collectively 2,250,000 
shares of our Series A Preferred Stock. &nbsp;Each share of the Series A 
Preferred Stock has voting rights equal to 100 shares of our common stock. 
&nbsp;As a result, our management team has the power to vote 261,301,216 shares 
of our common stock, which number exceeds our outstanding shares of our common 
stock. &nbsp;Furthermore, Mr. Wolfe owns all of the voting rights of Jack 
Frydman in 250,000 shares or our Series A Preferred Stock, which gives Mr. Wolfe
additional voting rights of 25,000,000 shares of our common stock. Therefore, 
Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, and Kaiser can control all matters submitted 
to our stockholders for approval and to control our management and affairs, 
including extraordinary transactions such as mergers and other changes of 
corporate control. &nbsp;Additionally, this concentration of voting power could 
discourage or prevent a potential takeover of Bravo Multinational  that might 
otherwise result in a stockholder receiving a premium over the market price for 
his shares. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 12. &nbsp;Security Ownership of Certain 
Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder 
Matters.&#148;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Even though our shares are 
publicly traded, an investor&#146;s shares may not be &#147;free-
trading.&#148;</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Investors should
understand that their shares of our common stock are not &#147;free-
trading&#148; merely because <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational 
</FONT>is a publicly-traded company. &nbsp;In order for the shares to become 
&#147;free-trading,&#148; the shares must be registered, or entitled to an 
exemption from registration under applicable law.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>The market price for our common
stock will most likely continue to be particularly volatile given our status as 
a relatively unknown company with a small and thinly traded public float, 
limited operating history and lack of net revenues which could lead to wide 
fluctuations in our share price. &nbsp;The price at which you purchased our 
common stock may not be indicative of the price that will prevail in the trading
market.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The market for 
our common stock is characterized by significant price volatility when compared 
to seasoned issuers, and we expect that our share price will continue to be more
volatile than a seasoned issuer for the indefinite future. &nbsp;As a 
consequence of this lack of liquidity, the trading of relatively small 
quantities of shares by our stockholders may disproportionately influence the 
price of those shares in either direction. &nbsp;The price for our shares could,
for example, decline precipitously in the event that a large number of shares of
our common stock are sold on the market without commensurate demand, as compared
to a seasoned issuer which could better absorb those sales without adverse 
impact on its share price.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Secondly, we are
a speculative or &#147;risky&#148; investment due to our lack of current 
revenues. &nbsp;As a consequence of this enhanced risk, more risk-adverse 
investors may, under the fear of losing all or most of their investment in the 
event of negative news or lack of progress, be more inclined to sell their 
shares on the market more quickly and at greater discounts than would be the 
case with the stock of a seasoned issuer.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>An investor may be unable to 
sell his common stock at or above his purchase price, which may result in 
substantial losses to the investor.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The following 
factors may add to the volatility in the price of our common stock: actual or 
anticipated variations in our quarterly or annual operating results; government 
regulations, announcements of significant acquisitions, strategic partnerships 
or joint ventures; our capital commitments; and additions or departures of our 
key personnel. &nbsp;Many of these factors are beyond our control and may 
decrease the market price of our common stock, regardless of our operating 
performance. &nbsp;We cannot make any predictions or projections as to what the 
prevailing market price for our common stock will be at any time, including as 
to whether our common stock will sustain the current market price, or as to what
effect the sale of shares or the availability of common stock for sale at any 
time will have on the prevailing market price.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>We may need to raise additional
capital. &nbsp;If we are unable to raise necessary additional capital, our 
business may fail or our operating results and our stock price may be materially
adversely affected.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We need to 
secure adequate funding. &nbsp;We hope to be able to fund our business through 
the revenues from operations. &nbsp;If our revenues are insufficient, we will 
need to raise the necessary capital through equity or debt offerings, which may 
reduce the value of our outstanding securities. &nbsp;We may be unable to secure
additional financing on favorable terms or at all.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Selling 
additional shares of our common stock, either privately or publicly, would 
dilute the equity interests of our stockholders. &nbsp;If we borrow more money, 
we will have to pay interest and may also have to agree to restrictions that 
limit our operating flexibility. &nbsp;If we are unable to obtain adequate 
financing, we may have to curtail our operations and our business would 
fail.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Our issuance of additional 
common stock in exchange for services or to repay debt would dilute a 
stockholder&#146;s proportionate ownership and voting rights and could have a 
negative impact on the market price of our common stock.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our board of 
directors may generally issue shares of common stock to pay for debt or 
services, without further approval by our stockholders based upon such factors 
as our board of directors may deem relevant at that time. &nbsp;It is likely 
that we will issue additional securities to pay for services and reduce debt in 
the future. &nbsp;In fact, our current employment agreements with Messrs. 
Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, and Kaiser, as well as various consultants, call for 
the issuance of shares of our common stock to pay a portion, if not all, of the 
compensation to be due to them. &nbsp;It is possible that we will issue 
additional shares of common stock under circumstances we may deem appropriate at
the time.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>The elimination of monetary 
liability against our directors, officers and employees under our certificate of
incorporation and the existence of indemnification rights for our directors, 
officers and employees may result in substantial expenditures by <FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational </FONT> and may discourage lawsuits 
against our directors, officers and employees.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our certificate 
of incorporation contains provisions which eliminate the liability of our 
directors for monetary damages to <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo 
Multinational </FONT> and our stockholders. &nbsp;Our bylaws also require us to 
indemnify our officers and directors. &nbsp;We may also have contractual
indemnification obligations under our agreements with our directors, officers 
and employees. &nbsp;The foregoing indemnification obligations could result in 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational </FONT> incurring substantial 
expenditures to cover the cost of settlement or damage awards against directors,
officers and employees, which we may be unable to recoup. &nbsp;These provisions
and resultant costs may also discourage <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo 
Multinational </FONT> from bringing a lawsuit against directors, officers and 
employees for breaches of their fiduciary duties, and may similarly discourage 
the filing of derivative litigation by our stockholders against our directors, 
officers and employees even though such actions, if successful, might otherwise 
benefit <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational </FONT> and our 
stockholders.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>13</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always"><B>Absence of dividends.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We have never 
paid or declared any dividends on our common stock. &nbsp;Likewise, we do not 
anticipate paying, in the near future, dividends or distributions on our common 
stock or our common stock which may be sold in the future. &nbsp;Any dividends 
will be declared at the discretion of our board of directors and will depend, 
among other things, on our earnings, our financial requirements for future 
operations and growth, and other facts as we may then deem appropriate.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Our directors have the right to
authorize the issuance of additional shares of our common stock.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our directors, 
within the limitations and restrictions contained in our certificate of 
incorporation and without further action by our stockholders, have the authority
to issue shares of common stock from time to time. &nbsp;Should we issue 
additional shares of our common stock at a later time, each stockholder&#146;s 
ownership interest in our stock would be proportionally reduced. &nbsp;No 
stockholder will have any preemptive right to acquire additional shares of our 
common stock, or any of our other securities.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>If we fail to remain current in
our reporting requirements, we could be removed from the OTCPK, which would 
limit the ability of broker-dealers to sell our securities and the ability of 
stockholders to sell their securities in the secondary market.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Companies 
trading on the OTCPK must be reporting issuers under Section 12 of the Exchange 
Act, and must be current in their reports under Section 13 of the Exchange Act, 
in order to maintain price quotation privileges on the OTCPK. &nbsp;If we fail 
to remain current in our reporting requirements, we could be removed from the 
OTCPK. &nbsp;In such an event, the market liquidity for our securities could be 
adversely affected by limiting the ability of broker-dealers to sell our 
securities and the ability of stockholders to sell their securities in the 
secondary market.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Our common stock is subject to 
the &#147;penny stock&#148; rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and
the trading market in our common stock will be limited, which would make 
transactions in our stock cumbersome and may reduce the investment value of our 
stock.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our shares of 
common stock are &#147;penny stocks&#148; because they are not registered on a 
national securities exchange or listed on an automated quotation system 
sponsored by a registered national securities association, pursuant to Rule 
3a51-1(a) under the Exchange Act. &nbsp;For any transaction involving a penny 
stock, unless exempt, the rules require:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">That a broker or dealer approve a person&#146;s account 
for transactions in penny stocks; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">That the broker or dealer receives from the investor a 
written agreement to the transaction, setting forth the identity and quantity of
the penny stock to be purchased.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The broker or 
dealer must also deliver, prior to any transaction in a penny stock, a 
disclosure schedule prescribed by the Securities and Exchange Commission 
relating to the penny stock market, which, in highlight form:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Sets forth the basis on which the broker or dealer made 
the suitability determination; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">That the broker or dealer received a signed, written 
agreement from the investor prior to the transaction.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Generally, 
brokers may be less willing to execute transactions in securities subject to the
&#147;penny stock&#148; rules. &nbsp;This may make it more difficult for 
investors to dispose of our common stock and cause a decline in the market value
of our stock.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt" 
align=justify>Disclosure also has to be made about the risks of investing in 
penny stocks in both public offerings and in secondary trading and about the 
commissions payable to both the broker-dealer and the registered representative,
current quotations for the securities and the rights and remedies available to 
an investor in cases of fraud in penny stock transactions. &nbsp;Finally, 
monthly statements have to be sent disclosing recent price information for the 
penny stock held in the account and information on the limited market in penny 
stocks.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>14</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>The market for penny stocks has
suffered in recent years from patterns of fraud and abuse.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Stockholders 
should be aware that, according to SEC Release No. 34-29093, the market for 
penny stocks has suffered in recent years from patterns of fraud and abuse. 
&nbsp;Such patterns include:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Control of the market for the security by one or a few 
broker-dealers that are often related to the promoter or issuer;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Manipulation of prices through prearranged matching of 
purchases and sales and false and misleading press releases;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Boiler room practices involving high-pressure sales 
tactics and unrealistic price projections by inexperienced 
salespersons;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman">Excessive and undisclosed bid-ask differential and 
markups by selling broker-dealers; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The wholesale dumping of the same securities by promoters
and broker-dealers after prices have been manipulated to a desired level, along 
with the resulting inevitable collapse of those prices and with consequential 
investor losses.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our management 
is aware of the abuses that have occurred historically in the penny stock 
market. &nbsp;Although we do not expect to be in a position to dictate the 
behavior of the market or of broker-dealers who participate in the market, 
management will strive within the confines of practical limitations to prevent 
the described patterns from being established with respect to our securities. 
&nbsp;The occurrence of these patterns or practices could increase the 
volatility of our share price.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item</B><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"> </FONT><B>1B. 
</B><B>Unresolved Staff Comments.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">None.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 2. </B><B>Properties.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We sub-lease 
1,200 square feet of office space at 590 York Road, Unit 3, Niagara On The Lake,
Ontario, CANADA L0S 1J0, from a company owned by Paul Parliament, our chairman 
and president, under a lease that runs from April 10, 2015, to May 20, 2017, at 
a rate of $1,860 per month. &nbsp;We believe that all of our facilities are 
adequate for at least the next 12 months. &nbsp;We expect that we could locate 
other suitable facilities at comparable rates, should we need more space.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>15</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">A description of
our mining properties is included in &#147;Item 1. &nbsp;Business&#148; and is 
incorporated herein by reference. &nbsp;We have written off the cost of the 
mining properties inasmuch as the value of any future revenue is unknown. 
&nbsp;We believe that we have satisfactory title to our mining properties, 
subject to liens for taxes not yet payable, liens incident to minor 
encumbrances, liens for credit arrangements and easements and restrictions that 
do not materially detract from the value of these properties, our interests in 
these properties, or the use of these properties in a business. &nbsp;We believe
that the mining properties are adequate and suitable for the conduct of a mining
business in the future.</P>
