align=center>100%</P>
    </TD><TD valign=top width=159.6><P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-
bottom:10pt" align=center>Unpatented Lode</P>
    </TD><TD valign=top width=112.4><P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-
bottom:10pt" align=center>20</P>
    </TD></TR>
  </TABLE>
</div>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">A patented 
mining claim is one which the federal government has passed title to the 
claimant, making the claimant the owner of the surface and mineral rights. 
&nbsp;An unpatented mining claim is one which is still owned by the federal 
government, but which the claimant has a right to possession to extracted 
minerals, provided the land is open to mineral entry.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>16</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 3. </B><B>Legal Proceedings.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In August 2010, 
Richard Corrigan, acting as a debtor in possession in his personal bankruptcy 
case, filed an adversary proceeding against us to recover amounts allegedly due 
under a consulting agreement dated July 1, 2009. &nbsp;The consulting agreement 
stated that Mr. Corrigan would provide certain consulting, mapping and assaying 
services on three lode claims owned by Goldland Holdings on War Eagle Mountain. 
&nbsp;The consulting agreement further provided that Mr. Corrigan&#146;s 
compensation would be a bonus of 150,000 shares of our common stock, valued by 
mutual agreement at approximately $150,000, and monthly consulting payments of 
$5,000 per month. &nbsp;The consulting agreement also provided that Mr. Corrigan
was entitled to monthly transportation expenses of $250 per month. &nbsp;We 
terminated Mr. Corrigan on December 8, 2009, for non-performance. &nbsp;In 2011,
Mr. Corrigan&#146;s filed a Chapter 7 proceeding seeking recovery of the alleged
$150,000 bonus and the balance of the unpaid consulting fees and travel expense 
allowance of $60,900, for a total of $210,900, plus interest and attorney 
fees.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">On June 19, 
2013, we learned that the court entered a default judgment against us in the 
amount of $284,449. &nbsp;We retained new counsel who filed a motion to vacate 
the default judgment. &nbsp;On September 19, 2013, the court set aside the 
default judgment. &nbsp;On September 15, 2014, the court ordered the payment of 
150,000 shares of our common shares to Mr. Corrigan to conclude the matter.
&nbsp;We issued the shares on January 13, 2015.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As of the date 
of this report, we are not aware of any other asserted or unasserted claims. 
&nbsp;Management will seek to minimize further disputes but recognizes the 
inevitability of legal action in today&#146;s business environment as an 
unfortunate price of conducting business.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 4. </B><B>(Removed and Reserved).</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Not 
applicable.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>PART II</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 5.</B><B> Market for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity, Related 
Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our common stock
was traded on the OTCBB from November 23, 2009, until December 16, 2013, under 
the symbol &#147;GHDC.&#148; &nbsp;Beginning on December 16, 2013, our common 
stock was traded on the OTCQB. &nbsp;Since October 16, 2014, our common stock 
has been traded on the OTCPK under the trading symbol &quot;GHDC.&quot; &nbsp;On
April 7, 2016, our trading symbol was changed from &quot;GHDC&quot; to 
&#147;BRVO.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The following 
table sets forth, taking into consideration the one for 10 reverse split of our 
common stock which occurred on March 6, 2014, the high and low bid prices for 
our common stock on the OTCBB, the OTCQB, and the OTCPK as reported by various 
market makers. &nbsp;The quotations do not reflect adjustments for retail mark-
ups, mark-downs, or commissions and may not necessarily reflect actual 
transactions.</P>

<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>17</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt">As of 
February 29, 2016 we had 263,405,812 shares of our common stock outstanding. 
&nbsp;Our shares of common stock are held by approximately 104 stockholders of 
record. &nbsp;The number of record holders was determined from the records of 
our transfer agent and does not include beneficial owners of our common stock 
whose shares are held in the names of various securities brokers, dealers, and 
registered clearing agencies.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Dividends</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">We have not paid or declared any dividends on our common 
stock, nor do we anticipate paying any cash dividends or other distributions on 
our common stock in the foreseeable future. &nbsp;Any future dividends will be 
declared at the discretion of our board of directors and will depend, among 
other things, on our earnings, if any, our financial requirements for future 
operations and growth, and other facts as our board of directors may then deem 
appropriate.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Preferred 
Stock</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">In addition to our authorized 1,000,000,000 shares of 
common stock, par value $0.0001 per share, Bravo Multinational  is authorized to
issue 5,000,000 shares of preferred stock, par value $0.0001 per share, of which
3,000,000 shares are issued and outstanding. &nbsp;There is no trading market 
for the shares of our preferred stock.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt" 
align=justify>Pursuant to a Certificate of Designation, Preferences and Rights 
for the Series A Preferred Stock, on March 24, 2015, our board of directors 
adopted a resolution designating the 5,000,000 shares of the preferred stock of 
Goldland Holdings, par value $0.0001 per share, as &#147;Series A Preferred 
Stock,&#148; which shall have certain designations, relative rights, and 
preferences, including:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Dividends</U></FONT>. &nbsp;Except as provided in the 
certificate of designation, the holders of outstanding shares of the Series A 
Preferred Stock shall be entitled to receive cash, stock, or other property, as 
dividends when, as, and if declared by our board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Redemption Rights</U></FONT>. &nbsp;Subject to the 
applicable provisions of Delaware law, <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo 
Multinational</FONT>, at the option of our directors, may at any time or from 
time to time redeem the whole or any part of the outstanding Series A Preferred 
Stock.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Liquidation Rights</U></FONT>. &nbsp;Upon the 
dissolution, liquidation or winding up of <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo 
Multinational</FONT>, whether voluntary or involuntary, the holders of the then 
outstanding shares of Series A Preferred Stock shall be entitled to receive out 
of the assets of <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> the sum
of $0.10 per share (the &#147;Liquidation Rate&#148;) before any payment or 
distribution shall be made on our common stock, or any other class of capital 
stock of <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> ranking junior 
to the Series A Preferred Stock.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Conversion of Series A Preferred Stock</U></FONT>. 
&nbsp;Subject to the terms of the certificate of designation, at any time, the 
holder of shares of the Series A Preferred Stock shall have the right, at such 
holder&#146;s option, to convert any number of shares of the Series A Preferred 
Stock into shares of our common stock at the rate of 10 fully paid and 
nonassessable shares of our common stock for each share of the Series A 
Preferred Stock so converted.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Preferred Status</U></FONT>. &nbsp;The rights of the 
shares of our common stock shall be subject to the preferences and relative 
rights of the shares of the Series A Preferred Stock. &nbsp;Without the prior 
written consent of the holders of not less than two-thirds (2/3) of the 
outstanding shares of the Series A Preferred Stock, <FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> shall not hereafter authorize or issue 
additional or other capital stock that is of senior or equal rank to the shares 
of the Series A Preferred Stock in respect of the preferences as to voting or 
conversion, as described in the certificate of designation, or distributions and
payments upon the liquidation, dissolution and winding up of <FONT FACE="Times 
New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT>.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Voting</U></FONT>. &nbsp;On all matters submitted to a
vote of the holders of our common stock, including, without limitation, the 
election of directors, a holder of shares of the Series A Preferred Stock shall 
be entitled to the number of votes on such matters equal to the number of shares
of the Series A Preferred Stock held by such holder multiplied by 100.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt">
</P>
</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>18</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:108pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:108pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"><U>Limitation on Beneficial Ownership</U></FONT>. 
&nbsp;Unless otherwise provided in the certificate of designation, <FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> shall not effect and shall 
have no obligation to effect any conversion of shares of Series A Preferred 
Stock, and no holder shall have the right to convert any shares of Series A 
Preferred Stock, to the extent that after giving effect to such conversion, the 
beneficial owner of such shares (together with such Person&#146;s affiliates) 
would have acquired, through conversion of shares of the Series A Preferred 
Stock or otherwise, beneficial ownership of a number of shares of the Common 
Stock that exceeds 4.99% (&#147;Maximum Percentage&#148;) of the number of 
shares of our common stock outstanding immediately after giving effect to such 
conversion.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt">A copy of the
Certificate of Designation, Preferences and Rights for the Series A Preferred 
Stock was filed with the SEC by Goldland Holdings on a Form 8-K/A on April 1, 
2015. &nbsp;Please refer to the filing for a complete description of the 
relative rights of our Series A Preferred Stock.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Securities</B></FONT><FONT

Plans</B></FONT></P>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our unregistered
securities were issued in reliance upon an exemption from registration pursuant 
to Section 4(a)(2) of the Securities Act or Rule 506(3) of Regulation D 
promulgated under the Securities Act. &nbsp;Each investor took his securities 
for investment purposes without a view to distribution and had access to 
information concerning us and our business prospects, as required by the 
Securities Act. &nbsp;In addition, there was no general solicitation or 
advertising for the purchase of our securities. &nbsp;Our securities were sold 
only to an accredited investor, as defined in the Securities Act with whom we 
had a direct personal preexisting relationship, and after a thorough discussion.
&nbsp;Each certificate contained a restrictive legend as required by the 
Securities Act. &nbsp;Finally, our stock transfer agent has been instructed not 
to transfer any of such securities, unless such securities are registered for 
resale or there is an exemption with respect to their transfer.</P>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 6. </B><B>Selected Financial Data.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Not 
applicable.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 7. </B><B>Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial 
Condition and Results of Operations.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">THE FOLLOWING 
DISCUSSION SHOULD BE READ TOGETHER WITH THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE 
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND RELATED NOTES INCLUDED ELSEWHERE IN THIS ANNUAL REPORT 
ON FORM 10-K.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The following 
discussion reflects our plan of operation. &nbsp;This discussion should be read 
in conjunction with the financial statements which are attached to this report. 
&nbsp;This discussion contains forward-looking statements, including statements 
regarding our expected financial position, business and financing plans. 
&nbsp;These statements involve risks and uncertainties. &nbsp;Our actual results
could differ materially from the results described in or implied by these 
forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including those 
discussed below and elsewhere in this report, particularly under the headings 
&#147;Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Unless the 
context otherwise suggests, &#147;we,&#148; &#147;our,&#148; &#147;us,&#148; and
similar terms, as well as references to &#147;GHDC&#148; and &#147;Goldland 
Holdings,&#148; all refer to Bravo Multinational Incorporated and our wholly-
owned subsidiaries, Universal Equipment SAS, Inc. and Bravo Gaming 
Corporation..</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As mentioned 
above, over the years, and prior to our entry into the business of the leasing 
of gaming equipment described below, we have been engaged in the business of 
owning and leasing mining claims. &nbsp;See &#147;Item 1. &nbsp;Business - 
Former Business.&#148;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">For a complete 
discussion of our former leasing of mining claims, please see our previous Form 
10-Ks, 10-Qs, and 8-Ks filed with the SEC. &nbsp;The following financial 
information relates only to revenues, expenses, and results of operations and 
other relevant information with respect to our former leasing of mining 
claims.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Going Concern</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2015, Goldland Holdings had an 
accumulated deficit during development stage of $23,701,207. &nbsp;Also, during 
the year ended December 31, 2015, we used net cash of $379,337 for operating 
activities. &nbsp;These factors raise substantial doubt about our ability to 
continue as a going concern.</FONT></P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>22</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">While we are 
attempting to commence operations and generate revenues, our cash position may 
not be significant enough to support our daily operations. &nbsp;Management 
intends to raise additional funds by way of an offering of our securities. 
&nbsp;Management believes that the actions presently being taken to further 
implement our business plan and generate revenues provide the opportunity for 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> to continue as a going 
concern. &nbsp;While we believe in the viability of our strategy to generate 
revenues and in our ability to raise additional funds, we may not be successful.
&nbsp;Our ability to continue as a going concern is dependent upon our 
capability to further implement our business plan and generate revenues.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New Roman Bold"><B>Results of 
Operations</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman Bold"
align=justify><I>Year Ended December 31, 2015, Compared to Year Ended December 
31, 2014.</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">There was no revenue in 2015. The revenue in 2014 
consisted solely from income generated from the leasing of gaming equipment. We 
reported losses from operations during the years ended December 31, 2015 of 
2,213,170, and 2014, of $2,943,120 respectively, a decrease of $729,950. 
&nbsp;The decrease in operating loss in 2015 &nbsp;as compared to 2014 was 
largely attributable in a decrease of professional fees of $1,076,639 and a 
decrease of stock compensation of &nbsp;$458,343, offset primarily by an 
increase in contract cancellation costs of $726,700 and an increase of salary of
$274,007.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Liquidity and Capital 
Resources</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The following 
table sets forth the major sources and uses of cash for the twelve months ended 
December 31, 2015, and 2014:</P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD 
width=188.3></TD><TD width=81.35></TD><TD width=97.35></TD><TD 
width=51.6></TD><TD width=60.2></TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=251.067>&nbsp;</TD><TD valign=top width=108.467><P 
style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>December 31, 2015</B></P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=129.8><P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>December 
31,</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>&nbsp;2014</B></P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=68.8><P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>$ 
Change</B></P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=80.267>&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=251.067><P style="margin:0pt">Net cash provided by 
(used in operating activities)</P>

paid in full on May 5, 2015. &nbsp;Consequently, no shares of our common stock 
were issued in connection with a conversion.</P>

<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>24</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><B>Critical 
Accounting Policies</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our financial 
statements and accompanying notes are prepared in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principles in the United States. &nbsp;Preparing financial 
statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that impact the
reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue, and expenses. &nbsp;These 
estimates and assumptions are affected by management&#146;s application of 
accounting policies. &nbsp;Critical accounting policies include revenue 
recognition and impairment of long-lived assets.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We recognize 
revenue in accordance with Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 101, &#147;Revenue 
Recognition in Financial Statements.&#148; &nbsp;Sales are recorded when 
products are shipped to customers. &nbsp;Provisions for discounts and rebates to
customers, estimated returns and allowances and other adjustments are provided 
for in the same period the related sales are recorded.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We evaluate our 
long-lived assets for financial impairment on a regular basis in accordance with
Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 144, &#147;Accounting for the 
Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; which evaluates the 
recoverability of long-lived assets not held for sale by measuring the carrying 
amount of the assets against the estimated discounted future cash flows 
associated with them. &nbsp;At the time such evaluations indicate that the 
future discounted cash flows of certain long-lived assets are not sufficient to 
recover the carrying value of such assets, the assets are adjusted to their fair
values.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><B>Quantitative and 
Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We conduct all 
of our transactions, including those with foreign suppliers and customers, in 
U.S. dollars. We are therefore not directly subject to the risks of foreign 
currency fluctuations and do not hedge or otherwise deal in currency instruments
in an attempt to minimize such risks. &nbsp;Demand from foreign customers and 
the ability or willingness of foreign suppliers to perform their obligations to 
us may be affected by the relative change in value of such customer or 
supplier&#146;s domestic currency to the value of the U.S. dollar. 
&nbsp;Furthermore, changes in the relative value of the U.S. dollar may change 
the price of our products relative to the prices of our foreign competitors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Stock-Based 
Compensation</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We recognize 
compensation cost for stock-based awards based on the estimated fair value of 
the award on date of grant. &nbsp;We measure compensation cost at the grant date
based on the fair value of the award and recognize compensation cost upon the 
probable attainment of a specified performance condition or over a service 
period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Recently Issued Accounting 
Pronouncements</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In October 2012,
the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Accounting Standards 
Update (ASU) 2012-04, &#147;Technical Corrections and Improvements&#148; in 
Accounting Standards Update No. 2012-04. &nbsp;The amendments in this update 
cover a wide range of Topics in the Accounting Standards Codification. 
&nbsp;These amendments include technical corrections and improvements to the 
Accounting Standards Codification and conforming amendments related to fair 
value measurements. &nbsp;The amendments in this update were effective for 
fiscal periods beginning after December 15, 2012. &nbsp;The adoption of ASU 
2012-04 is not expected to have a material impact on our financial position or 
results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In August 2012, 
the FASB issued ASU 2012-03, &#147;Technical Amendments and Corrections to SEC 
Sections: Amendments to SEC Paragraphs Pursuant to SEC Staff Accounting Bulletin
(SAB) No. 114, Technical Amendments Pursuant to SEC Release No. 33-9250, and 
Corrections Related to FASB Accounting Standards Update 2010-22 (SEC 
Update)&#148; in Accounting Standards Update No. 2012-03. &nbsp;This update 
amends various SEC paragraphs pursuant to the issuance of SAB No. 114. &nbsp;The
adoption of ASU 2012-03 is not expected to have a material impact on our 
financial position or results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In July 2012, 
the FASB issued ASU 2012-02, &#147;Intangibles &#150; Goodwill and Other (Topic 
350): Testing Indefinite-Lived Intangible Assets for Impairment&#148; in 
Accounting Standards Update No. 2012-02. &nbsp;This update amends ASU 2011-08, 
Intangibles &#150; Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Testing Indefinite-Lived 
Intangible Assets for Impairment and permits an entity first to assess 
qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that an 
indefinite-lived intangible asset is impaired as a basis for determining whether
it is necessary to perform the quantitative impairment test in accordance with 
Subtopic 350-30, Intangibles - Goodwill and Other - General Intangibles Other 
than Goodwill. &nbsp;The amendments are effective for annual and interim 
impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after September 15, 2012. 
&nbsp;Early adoption is permitted, including for annual and interim impairment 
tests performed as of a date before July 27, 2012, if a public entity&#146;s 
financial statements for the most recent annual or interim period have not yet 
been issued or, for nonpublic entities, have not yet been made available for 
issuance. &nbsp;The adoption of ASU 2012-02 is not expected to have a material 
impact on our financial position or results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In December 
2011, the FASB issued ASU 2011-12, &#147;Deferral of the Effective Date for 
Amendments to the Presentation of Reclassifications of Items out of Accumulated 
Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards Update No. 2011-05.
&nbsp;This update defers the requirement to present items that are reclassified 
from accumulated other comprehensive income to net income in both the statement 
of income where net income is presented and the statement where other 
comprehensive income is presented. &nbsp;The adoption of ASU 2011-12 is not 
expected to have a material impact on our financial position or results of 
operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In December 
2011, the FASB issued ASU No. 2011-11 &#147;Balance Sheet: Disclosures about 
Offsetting Assets and Liabilities&#148; (&#147;ASU 2011-11&#148;). &nbsp;This 
Update requires an entity to disclose information about offsetting and related 
arrangements to enable users of its financial statements to understand the 
effect of those arrangements on its financial position. &nbsp;The objective of 
this disclosure is to facilitate comparison between those entities that prepare 
their financial statements on the basis of U.S. GAAP and those entities that 
prepare their financial statements on the basis of IFRS. &nbsp;The amended 
guidance is effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after January
1, 2013, and interim periods within those annual periods. &nbsp;We are currently
evaluating the impact, if any, that the adoption of this pronouncement may have 
on our results of operations or financial position.</P>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 9. </B><B>Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on 
Accounting and Financial Disclosure.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">During the last 
two fiscal years, we have had no disagreements with our accountants on 
accounting and financial disclosure.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:35.1pt">However, on 
<FONT FACE="Times">November 4, 2015, the registrant was notified by its 
independent certifying accountant, W.T. Uniack &amp; Co. CPAs, P.C. 
(&#147;Uniack&#148;) that Uniack was resigning as the registrant&#146;s 
independent auditor.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:35.1pt; font-
family:Times"><FONT FACE="Times">Uniack&#146;s reports on the registrant&#146;s 
financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2012, and December 31, 
2013, did not contain an adverse opinion or a disclaimer of opinion, and were 
not qualified or modified as to uncertainty, audit scope, or accounting 
principles. &nbsp;Uniack did not prepare a report for 2014 or perform any review
of the registrant&#146;s financial statements for 2015.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:35.1pt; font-
family:Times">The decision to accept the resignation of Uniack was made by the 
registrant&#146;s board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:5pt; text-indent:35.1pt; font-
family:Times">During the two most recent fiscal years and any subsequent interim
period through November 4, 2015, there have not been any disagreements between 
the registrant and Uniack on any matter of accounting principles or practices, 
financial statement disclosure, or auditing scope or procedure, which 
disagreements, if not resolved to the satisfaction of Uniack, would have caused 
it to make reference to the subject matter of the disagreements in connection 
with its reports on the financial statements for such periods.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">On November 9, 2015, the registrant engaged Scrudato 
&amp; Co. CPA (&#147;Scrudato&#148;) as the registrant&#146;s independent 
accountants to report on the registrant&#146;s balance sheets </FONT><FONT 
FACE="Times">for the year ended December 31, 2014</FONT>, and the related 
combined statements of income, stockholders&#146; equity and cash flows for the 
years then ended. &nbsp;The decision to appoint Scrudato was approved by the 
registrant&#146;s board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:8.35pt; text-indent:36pt">During the 
registrant&#146;s two most recent fiscal years and any subsequent interim period
prior to the engagement of Scrudato, neither the registrant nor anyone on the 
registrant&#146;s behalf consulted with Scrudato regarding either (i) the 
application of accounting principles to a specified transaction, either 
completed or proposed; or the type of audit opinion that might be rendered on 
the registrant&#146;s financial statements, and either a written report was 
provided to the registrant or oral advice was provided that the new accountant 
concluded was an important factor considered by the registrant in reaching a 
decision as to the accounting, auditing or financial reporting issue; or (ii) 
any matter that was either the subject of a disagreement (as defined in 
paragraph 304(a)(1)(iv) and the related instructions to Regulation S-K) or a 
reportable event (as described in paragraph 304(a)(1)(v) of Regulation S-K).</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt; font-
family:Times"><FONT FACE="Times">The registrant provided Uniack with a copy of 
the disclosures it made in its Current Report on Form 8-K on November 10, 2015, 
which Uniack received no later than the day that the disclosures were filed with
the SEC. &nbsp;The registrant requested that Uniack furnish the registrant with 
a letter addressed to the SEC stating whether it agrees with the statements made
by the registrant in response to Item 304(a) of Regulation S-K, and, if not, 
stating the respects in which it does not agree. &nbsp;Uniack furnished the 
requested letter and agreed with the disclosure made by the registrant. &nbsp;A 
copy of Uniack&#146;s letter was filed with the SEC on November 16, 
2015.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The financial statements included in this report were 
audited by Scrudato &amp; Co. CPA.</FONT></P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>26</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 9A. </B><B>Controls and Procedures.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">See Item 9A(T) 
below.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<p><B>Item 9A(T).</B>
    <B>Controls and Procedures.</B>
</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-
indent:39.6pt"><I>Evaluation of Disclosure and Controls and Procedures.</I> 
&nbsp;We carried out an evaluation, under the supervision and with the 
participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and 
principal financial officer, of the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and
procedures (as defined) in Exchange Act Rules 13a &#150; 15(c) and 15d &#150; 
15(e)). &nbsp;Based upon that evaluation, our chief executive officer and chief 
financial officer concluded that, as of the end of the period ended December 31,
2015, our disclosure controls and procedures were not effective (1) to ensure 
that information required to be disclosed by us in reports that we file or 
submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, 
within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms and (2) to 
ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in the reports that we 
file or submit under the Exchange Act is accumulated and communicated to us, 
including our chief executive and chief financial officers, as appropriate to 
allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-indent:39.6pt">The term 
disclosure controls and procedures means controls and other procedures of an 
issuer that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by 
the issuer in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act (15 
U.S.C. 78a, <I>et seq.</I>) is recorded, processed, summarized and reported, 
within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms. 
&nbsp;Disclosure controls and procedures include, without limitation, controls 
and procedures designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by 
an issuer in the reports that it files or submits under the Exchange Act is 
accumulated and communicated to the issuer&#146;s management, including its 
principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing 
similar functions, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required 
disclosure.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-indent:39.6pt">Our 
management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, 
does not expect that our disclosure controls and procedures or our internal 
controls over financial reporting will prevent all error and all fraud. &nbsp;A 
control system, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only 
reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system 
are met. &nbsp;Further, the design of a control system must reflect the fact 
that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be 
considered relative to their costs. &nbsp;Because of inherent limitations in all
control systems, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or 
detect misstatements, and no evaluation of controls can provide absolute 
assurance that all control issues and instances of fraud, if any, within the 
registrant have been detected. &nbsp;Also, projections of any evaluation of 
effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become
inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance 
with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-
indent:39.6pt"><I>Management&#146;s Annual Report on Internal Control over 
Financial Reporting.</I> &nbsp;Our management is responsible for establishing 
and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in
Rule 13a-15(f) under the Exchange Act. &nbsp;Our internal control over financial
reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the 
reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements 
for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally 
accepted in the United States.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-indent:39.6pt">The term 
internal control over financial reporting is defined as a process designed by, 
or under the supervision of, the issuer&#146;s principal executive and principal
financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, and effected by the
issuer&#146;s board of directors, management and other personnel, to provide
reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the 
preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with 
generally accepted accounting principles and includes those policies and 
procedures that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:75.6pt; text-
indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; padding-left:75.6pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable
detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of our 
assets;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:75.6pt; text-
indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; padding-left:75.6pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Provide reasonable assurance that transactions are 
recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in 
accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and 
expenditures of the issuer are being made only in accordance with authorizations
of management and directors of the issuer; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:75.6pt; text-
indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; padding-left:75.6pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or 
timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the 
issuer&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial 
statements.</FONT></P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>27</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-indent:39.6pt">Our 
management assessed the effectiveness of our internal control over financial 
reporting as of December 31, 2015. &nbsp;In making this assessment, our 
management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring 
Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in Internal Control-Integrated 
Framework.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-indent:39.6pt"><I>Changes 
in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.</I> &nbsp;There have been no 
changes in the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting 
through November 30, 2015 or during the period ended December 31, 2015, that 
materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the 
registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt; text-
indent:39.6pt"><I>Independent Registered Accountant&#146;s Internal Control 
Attestation.</I> &nbsp;This report does not include an attestation report of the
registrant&#146;s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control 
over financial reporting. &nbsp;Management&#146;s report was not subject to 
attestation by the registrant&#146;s registered public accounting firm pursuant 
to temporary rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the 
registrant to provide only management&#146;s report in this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:9.15pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Remediation
plans for material weaknesses over internal controls.</I> &nbsp;Our plans to 
mitigate material weaknesses in disclosure controls and procedures for future 
filings will be dependent on our ability to obtain adequate financing to fund 
development of our financial reporting infrastructure. &nbsp;At this time it is 
not cost beneficial for us to utilize capital to focus on mitigating financial 
reporting weaknesses; however, we expect to implement a plan for remediation of 
these deficiencies when sufficient funding to implement such a plan is 
available.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:9.15pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 9B. </B><B>Other Information.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">None.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=center><B>PART III</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=center>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 10.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt"><B>Directors, 
Executive Officers and Corporate Governance.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The following 
table sets forth information concerning the directors and executive officers of 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> as of the date of this 
report:</P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR><TD

<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>28</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The members of 
our board of directors are subject to change from time to time by the vote of 
the stockholders at special or annual meetings to elect directors. &nbsp;Our 
current board of directors consists of three directors, who have expertise in
the business of <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT>.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The foregoing 
notwithstanding, except as otherwise provided in any resolution or resolutions 
of the board, directors who are elected at an annual meeting of stockholders, 
and directors elected in the interim to fill vacancies and newly created 
directorships, will hold office for the term for which elected and until their 
successors are elected and qualified or until their earlier death, resignation 
or removal.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Whenever the 
holders of any class or classes of stock or any series thereof are entitled to 
elect one or more directors pursuant to any resolution or resolutions of the 
board, vacancies and newly created directorships of such class or classes or 
series thereof may generally be filled by a majority of the directors elected by
such class or classes or series then in office, by a sole remaining director so 
elected or by the unanimous written consent or the affirmative vote of a 
majority of the outstanding shares of such class or classes or series entitled 
to elect such director or directors. &nbsp;Officers are elected annually by the 
directors. &nbsp;There are no family relationships among our directors and 
officers.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We may employ 
additional management personnel, as our board of directors deems necessary. 
&nbsp;<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> has not identified
or reached an agreement or understanding with any other individuals to serve in 
management positions, but does not anticipate any problem in employing qualified
staff.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">A description of
the business experience for each of the directors and executive officers of 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> is set forth below.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Paul Parliament 
has been a member of our board since October 31, 2012. &nbsp;For the last five 
years, Mr. Parliament has served as president of The Parliament Corporation and 
The Parliament Apartment Corporation, which are in the real estate business. 
&nbsp;Mr. Parliament has over 28 years as a successful real estate developer, 
and as president of &#147;Marsadi Layne Properties, Inc.,&#148; &#147;The 
Parliament Corporation,&#148; &#147;P.D.P Developments, Inc.,&#148; and 
&#147;The Parliament Apartment Corporation.&#148; &nbsp;Mr. Parliament has 
knowledge of property acquisitions, corporate finance, planning, permitting, 
staffing, management, and strategic business planning.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Martin Wolfe is 
a BA, CA (Chartered Accountant) and CPA (Chartered Professional Accountant) who 
received his designation in 1980. &nbsp;Mr. Wolfe has served on the board of the
registrant since June 2, 2014, and is currently our chief financial officer. 
&nbsp;Mr. Wolfe has over 35 years of experience in both public practice and in 
industry. &nbsp;Currently, Mr. Wolfe, in addition to operating as a sole 
practitioner, provides consulting services to the insolvency and restructuring 
industry.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Douglas Brooks 
has had a career in real estate. &nbsp;From 1994 to 2000, he was secretary and 
director of Marsadi Layne Properties Inc., a large real estate property manager 
and developer in Southern Ontario. &nbsp;From 1996 to 2015, Mr. Brooks has been 
president and chief executive officer of Rentcom Plus Inc., a privately owned 
real estate based corporation. &nbsp;Mr. Brooks has also been involved in 
corporate business including property management, finance and real estate 
redevelopment. &nbsp;He is a Member Broker and Broker of Record for the Real 
Estate Council of Ontario.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Richard Kaiser, 
the registrant's corporate secretary, has served as Co-owner of Yes 
International since July 1991, a full service investor relations and venture 
capital firm. &nbsp;He has a Bachelor of Arts degree in International Economics 
from Oakland University (formerly known as Michigan State University-Honors 
College).</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">On November 9, 
2015, the registrant added Allen Simon, as a Senior Advisor to the Executive 
Committee of the registrant. &nbsp;Mr. Simon has no voting privileges with
respect to his position.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Committees of the Board</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We currently 
have an Executive Committee of our board of directors which was established on 
March 24, 2015. &nbsp;However, we do not currently have an Audit, Executive, 
Finance, Compensation, or Nominating Committee, or any other committee of the 
board of directors. &nbsp;We have adopted a charter for the Executive Committee 
as well as charters for the other committees, in the event that we elect to 
implement them. &nbsp;Copies of the charters for each committee have been 
previously filed with the SEC.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The 
responsibilities of these committees are fulfilled by our board of directors and
all of our directors participate in such responsibilities, none of whom is 
&#147;independent&#148; as defined under Rule 4200(a)(15) of the NASD&#146;s 
listing standards described below, as our financial constraints have made it 
extremely difficult to attract and retain qualified independent board members. 
&nbsp;Since we do not have any of the subject committees, other than our 
Executive Committee, our entire board of directors participates in all of the 
considerations with respect to our audit, compensation and nomination 
deliberations.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>29</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Rule 4200(a)(15)
of the NASD&#146;s listing standards defines an &#147;independent director&#148;
as a person other than an executive officer or employee of the company or any 
other individual having a relationship which, in the opinion of the 
issuer&#146;s board of directors, would interfere with the exercise of 
independent judgment in carrying out the responsibilities of a director. 
&nbsp;The following persons shall not be considered independent:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director who is, or at any time during the past three 
years was, employed by the company;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director who accepted or who has a Family Member who 
accepted any compensation from the company in excess of $120,000 during any 
period of twelve consecutive months within the three years preceding the 
determination of independence, other than the following: (i) compensation for 
board or board committee service; (ii) compensation paid to a Family Member who 
is an employee (other than as an executive officer) of the company; or (iii) 
benefits under a tax-qualified retirement plan, or non-discretionary 
compensation. &nbsp;Provided, however, that in addition to the requirements 
contained in this paragraph, audit committee members are also subject to 
additional, more stringent requirements under Rule 4350(d).</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director who is a Family Member of an individual who 
is, or at any time during the past three years was, employed by the company as 
an executive officer;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director who is, or has a Family Member who is, a 
partner in, or a controlling stockholder or an executive officer of, any 
organization to which the company made, or from which the company received, 
payments for property or services in the current or any of the past three fiscal
years that exceed five percent of the recipient&#146;s consolidated gross 
revenues for that year, or $200,000, whichever is more, other than the 
following: (i) payments arising solely from investments in the company&#146;s 
securities; or (ii) payments under non-discretionary charitable contribution 
matching programs.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director of the issuer who is, or has a Family Member 
who is, employed as an executive officer of another entity where at any time 
during the past three years any of the executive officers of the issuer serve on
the compensation committee of such other entity; or</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A director who is, or has a Family Member who is, a 
current partner of the company&#146;s outside auditor, or was a partner or 
employee of the registrant&#146;s outside auditor who worked on the 
company&#146;s audit at any time during any of the past three years.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We hope to add 
qualified independent members of our board of directors at a later date, 
depending upon our ability to reach and maintain financial stability.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Executive Committee</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In accordance 
with Article III of our Bylaws, our board of directors has established an 
Executive Committee which consists of members who have been appointed by the 
board of directors. &nbsp;The initial chairman of the Executive Committee is 
Paul Parliament. &nbsp;Thereafter, the chairman of the Executive Committee shall
be appointed by the members of the Executive Committee. &nbsp;The remaining two 
members of the Executive Committee are Martin Wolfe, and Douglas Brooks. 
&nbsp;The members of the Executive Committee shall serve at the pleasure of the 
board of directors or until their successors shall be duly designated. 
&nbsp;Vacancies in the Executive Committee shall be filled by the board of 
directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">During the 
intervals between the meetings of the board of directors, the Executive 
Committee shall have and may exercise all of the authority of the board of 
directors in the management of the business affairs of the registrant to the 
extent authorized by the resolution providing for the Executive Committee or by 
subsequent resolution adopted by a majority of the whole board of directors. 
&nbsp;This authorization is subject to the limitations imposed by law, the 
Bylaws of the registrant or the board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Audit Committee</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The entire board
of directors performs the functions of an audit committee, but no written 
charter governs the actions of the board when performing the functions of what 
would generally be performed by an audit committee. &nbsp;The board approves the
selection of our independent accountants and meets and interacts with the 
independent accountants to discuss issues related to financial reporting. 
&nbsp;In addition, the board reviews the scope and results of the audit with the
independent accountants, reviews with management and the independent accountants
our annual operating results, considers the adequacy of our internal accounting 
procedures and considers other auditing and accounting matters including fees to
be paid to the independent auditor and the performance of the independent 
auditor. &nbsp;At the present time, Paul Parliament, our chief executive officer
and Martin Wolfe, our chief financial officer, are considered to be our experts 
in financial and accounting matters.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Nomination Committee</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt" 
align=justify>Our size and the size of our board, at this time, do not require a
separate nominating committee. &nbsp;When evaluating director nominees, our 
directors consider the following factors:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The appropriate size of our board of 
directors;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Our needs with respect to the particular talents and 
experience of our directors;</FONT></P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>30</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The knowledge, skills and experience of nominees, 
including experience in finance, administration or public service, in light of 
prevailing business conditions and the knowledge, skills and experience already 
possessed by other members of the board;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Experience in political affairs;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Experience with accounting rules and practices; 
and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The desire to balance the benefit of continuity with the 
periodic injection of the fresh perspective provided by new board 
members.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our goal is to 
assemble a board that brings together a variety of perspectives and skills 
derived from high quality business and professional experience. &nbsp;In doing 
so, the board will also consider candidates with appropriate non-business 
backgrounds.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Other than the 
foregoing, there are no stated minimum criteria for director nominees, although 
the board may also consider such other factors as it may deem are in our best 
interests as well as our stockholders. &nbsp;In addition, the board identifies 
nominees by first evaluating the current members of the board willing to 
continue in service. &nbsp;Current members of the board with skills and 
experience that are relevant to our business and who are willing to continue in 
service are considered for re-nomination. &nbsp;If any member of the board does 
not wish to continue in service or if the board decides not to re-nominate a 
member for re-election, the board then identifies the desired skills and 
experience of a new nominee in light of the criteria above. &nbsp;Current 
members of the board are polled for suggestions as to individuals meeting the 
criteria described above. &nbsp;The board may also engage in research to 
identify qualified individuals. &nbsp;To date, we have not engaged third parties
to identify or evaluate or assist in identifying potential nominees, although we
reserve the right in the future to retain a third party search firm, if 
necessary. &nbsp;The board does not typically consider stockholder nominees 
because it believes that its current nomination process is sufficient to 
identify directors who serve our best interests.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Section 16(a) Beneficial 
Ownership Reporting Compliance</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Under Section 
16(a) of the Exchange Act, our directors and certain of our officers, and 
persons holding more than 10 percent of our common stock are required to file 
forms reporting their beneficial ownership of our common stock and subsequent 
changes in that ownership with the United States Securities and Exchange 
Commission. &nbsp;Such persons are also required to furnish <FONT FACE="Times 
New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> with copies of all forms so filed.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Based solely 
upon a review of copies of such forms filed on Forms 3, 4, and 5, and amendments
thereto furnished to us, we believe that as of November 30, 2015, all of our 
executive officers, directors and greater than 10 percent beneficial owners have
complied on a timely basis with all Section 16(a) filing requirements. 
&nbsp;However, during 2014, our then current executive officers, directors and 
greater than 10 percent beneficial owners did not comply on a timely basis with 
all Section 16(a) filing requirements as follows:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Richard Kaiser &#150; Form 3.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Douglas Brooks &#150; Form 3.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Martin Wolfe Form - 4 and 5.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Paul Parliament - Form 4.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Julios Kosta &#150; Form 3.</FONT></P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>31</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Communication with 
Directors</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Stockholders and
other interested parties may contact any of our directors by writing to them at 
Bravo Multinational Incorporated, Post Office Box 299, St. David&#146;s Postal 
Office, St. David&#146;s, Ontario, CANADA L0S 1P0, Attention: Vice 
President.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Our board has 
approved a process for handling letters received by us and addressed to any of 
our directors. &nbsp;Under that process, our vice president &nbsp;reviews all 
such correspondence and regularly forwards to the directors a summary of all 
such correspondence, together with copies of all such correspondence that, in 
the opinion of our vice president , deal with functions of the board or 
committees thereof or that he otherwise determines requires their attention. 
&nbsp;Directors may at any time review a log of all correspondence received by 
us that are addressed to members of the board and request copies of such 
correspondence.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always"><B>Conflicts of Interest</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">With respect to 
transactions involving real or apparent conflicts of interest, we have adopted
written policies and procedures which require that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The fact of the relationship or interest giving rise to 
the potential conflict be disclosed or known to the directors who authorize or 
approve the transaction prior to such authorization or approval;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The transaction be approved by a majority of our 
disinterested outside directors; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The transaction be fair and reasonable to us at the time 
it is authorized or approved by our directors.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Code of Ethics for Senior 
Executive Officers and Senior Financial Officers</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We have adopted 
an amended Code of Ethics for Senior Executive Officers and Senior Financial 
Officers that applies to our president, chief executive officer, chief operating
officer, chief financial officer, and all financial officers, including the 
principal accounting officer. &nbsp;The code provides as follows:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Each officer is responsible for full, fair, accurate, 
timely and understandable disclosure in all periodic reports and financial 
disclosures required to be filed by us with the Securities and Exchange 
Commission or disclosed to our stockholders and/or the public.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Each officer shall immediately bring to the attention of 
the audit committee, or disclosure compliance officer, any material information 
of which the officer becomes aware that affects the disclosures made by us in 
our public filings and assist the audit committee or disclosure compliance 
officer in fulfilling its responsibilities for full, fair, accurate, timely and 
understandable disclosure in all periodic reports required to be filed with the 
Securities and Exchange Commission.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Each officer shall promptly notify our general counsel, 
if any, or the president or chief executive officer as well as the audit 
committee of any information he may have concerning any violation of our Code of
Business Conduct or our Code of Ethics, including any actual or apparent 
conflicts of interest between personal and professional relationships, involving
any management or other employees who have a significant role in our financial 
reporting, disclosures or internal controls.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Each officer shall immediately bring to the attention of 
our general counsel, if any, the president or the chief executive officer and 
the audit committee any information he may have concerning evidence of a 
material violation of the securities or other laws, rules or regulations 
applicable to us and the operation of our business, by us or any of our 
agents.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:72pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Any waiver of this Code of Ethics for any officer must be
approved, if at all, in advance by a majority of the independent directors 
serving on our board of directors. &nbsp;Any such waivers granted will be 
publicly disclosed in accordance with applicable rules, regulations and listing 
standards.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">We have posted a
copy of our Code of Ethics on our website. &nbsp;We will provide to any person 
without charge, upon request, a copy of our Code of Ethics. &nbsp;Any such 
request should be directed to our corporate secretary at the address listed 
below in the next paragraph. &nbsp;The information contained in our website 
shall not constitute part of this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>32</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt; page-break-before:always"><B>Item 11. </B><B>Executive 
Compensation.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt; page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Summary of Cash and Certain 
Other Compensation</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">At present, 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> has four executive 
officers. &nbsp;Beginning in March 2015, the compensation program for our 
executives consists of three key elements:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">A base salary;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Additional compensation; and</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-
18pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:18pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Periodic grants and/or options of our common 
stock.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Base 
Salary</I>. &nbsp;Our executive officers receive compensation based on such 
factors as competitive industry salaries, a subjective assessment of the 
contribution and experience of the officer, and the specific recommendation by 
our board of directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Additional 
Compensation</I>. &nbsp;Each of our officers receives additional compensation as
provided in the officer&#146;s employment agreement. &nbsp;All payments to 
officers must be approved by our board of directors or compensation committee 
based on the individual officer&#146;s performance and company performance.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Stock 
Incentive</I>. &nbsp;Stock grants and options are awarded to executive officers 
based on their positions and individual performance. &nbsp;Stock grants and 
options provide incentive for the creation of stockholder value over the long 
term and aid significantly in the recruitment and retention of executive 
officers. &nbsp;The board of directors or compensation committee considers the 
recommendations of the chief executive officer for stock grants and options to 
executive officers (other than the chief executive officer) and approves, 
disapproves or modifies such recommendation. &nbsp;Stock grants and options for 
our executive officers will be recommended and approved by our board of 
directors. &nbsp;See &#147;Market Price of and Dividends on our Common Equity 
and Related Stockholder Matters - Securities Authorized for Issuance under 
Equity Compensation Plans.&#148;</P>

New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> Summary Compensation Table</B></P>
