<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(1) Mr. Pierre Quilliam was our former chairman of 
the board of directors, chief executive officer, and president, and a former 
director.</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(2) Mr. Breitkreuz was our former chief operating 
officer and a former director.</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(3)Mr. Christian Quilliam was one of our former 
officers. &nbsp;Mr. Christian Quilliam is the son of Mr. Pierre 
Quilliam.</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(4)Mr. Ridenour was our former chief financial 
officer and a former director.</P><br>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>33</P>
<p style="margin:0pt">
<p style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</p>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(5)Mr. Parliament is our chief executive officer, 
president, and chairman of the board.</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(6)Mr. Wolfe is our chief financial officer, and 
director.</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(7)Mr. Brooks is our vice president and 
director</P><br>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; text-
indent:178pt; font-size:8pt">(8)Mr. Kaiser is our corporate secretary, and 
governance officer.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:35.3pt">Mr. Pierre 
Quilliam&#146;s compensation was determined, using industry standard comparable 
computations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:35.3pt">Mr. 
Breitkreuz&#146; compensation was determined, using industry standard comparable
computations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:35.3pt">Mr. 
Christian Quilliam&#146;s compensation was determined, using standard comparable
computations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:35.3pt">Mr. 
Ridenour&#146;s compensation was determined, using standard comparable 
computations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:4.15pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:35.3pt">All 2015 
current executive compensation has been calculated using standard comparable 
computations then adjusted to reflect the current economic condition of the 
registrant.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><B>Outstanding 
Equity Awards at Fiscal Year-End</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">None.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">Goldland Holdings </FONT> Employment Agreements</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As of November 
30, 2015, <FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> has employment
agreements with Paul Parliament, our chairman of the board of directors, chief 
executive officer, and president, Martin Wolfe, our chief financial officer, 
principal accounting officer, and treasurer, Douglas Brooks, our Vice- 
President, and Richard Kaiser, our Secretary and Corporate Governance 
Officer.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Paul 
Parliament Employment Agreement.</I> &nbsp;On March 24, 2015, the registrant and
Paul Parliament executed an employment agreement, which provides for a term of 
two years, and a base salary of $42,000 per year, payable in equal monthly 
installments of $3,500 paid in the restricted shares of our common stock of the 
company on the 1st day of each month during the term of Mr. Parliament&#146;s 
employment, pro rated for any partial employment period. &nbsp;Mr. Parliament is
to devote part of his time and attention to the performance of his duties of 
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In addition to 
the base compensation, Mr. Parliament shall be entitled to receive additional 
compensation of $108,000 per year, payable in equal monthly installments of 
$9,000 paid in restricted shares of our common stock on the 1st day of each 
month during the term of Mr. Parliament&#146;s employment, pro rated for any 
partial employment period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Douglas 
Brooks Employment Agreement.</I> &nbsp;On September 25, 2015, the registrant and
Douglas Brooks executed an employment agreement, which provides for a term of 
two years, and a base salary of $42,000 per year, payable in equal monthly 
installments of $3,500 paid in the restricted shares of our common stock of the 
company on the 1st day of each month during the term of Mr. Brooks&#146; 
employment, pro rated for any partial employment period. &nbsp;Mr. Brooks is to 
devote part of his time and attention to the performance of his duties of <FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT>.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In addition to 
the base compensation, Mr. Brooks shall be entitled to receive additional 
compensation of $78,000 per year, payable in equal monthly installments of 
$6,500 paid in restricted shares of our common stock on the 1st day of each 
month during the term of Mr. Brooks&#146; employment, pro rated for any partial 
employment period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Martin Wolfe
Employment Agreement.</I> &nbsp;On March 24, 2015, the registrant and Martin 
Wolfe executed an employment agreement, which provides for a term of one year, 
and a base salary of $42,000 per year, payable in equal monthly installments of 
$3,500 paid in the restricted shares of our common stock of the company on the 
1st day of each month during the term of Mr. Wolfe&#146;s employment, pro rated 
for any partial employment period. &nbsp;Mr. Wolfe is to devote part of his time
and attention to the performance of his duties of <FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT>.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In addition to 
the base compensation, Mr. Wolfe shall be entitled to receive additional 
compensation of $58,000 per year, payable in equal monthly installments of 
$4,833.33 paid in restricted shares of our common stock on the 1st day of each 
month during the term of Mr. Wolfe&#146;s employment, pro rated for any partial 
employment period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt"><I>Richard 
Kaiser Employment Agreement.</I> &nbsp;On March 24, 2015, the registrant and 
Richard Kaiser executed an employment agreement, which provides for a term of 
two years, and a base salary of $42,000 per year, payable in equal monthly 
installments of $3,500 paid in the restricted shares of our common stock of the 
company on the 1st day of each month during the term of Mr. Kaiser&#146;s 
employment, pro rated for any partial employment period. &nbsp;Mr. Kaiser is to 
devote part of his time and attention to the performance of his duties of <FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT>.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>34</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In addition to 
the base compensation, Mr. Kaiser shall be entitled to receive additional 
compensation of $38,000 per year, payable in equal monthly installments of 
$3,166.67 paid in restricted shares of our common stock on the 1st day of each 
month during the term of Mr. Kaiser&#146;s employment, pro rated for any partial
employment period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Copies of each 
of the employment agreements with Messrs. Parliament, Brooks, Wolfe, and Kaiser 
are attached as exhibits to this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Goldland Holdings Director 
Compensation</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As a result of 
the election of Mr. Brooks as a director of the registrant, Mr. Brooks was 
awarded 2,000,000 shares of the restricted common stock of the registrant. 
&nbsp;Moreover, due to his election as a director of the registrant, Mr. Brooks 
made a $100,000 direct investment in the registrant on October 1, 2015, in 
exchange for a convertible promissory note, providing for conversion rights into
common stock of the registrant based on the registrant&#146;s common stock price
low as of September 23, 2015, which was $0.0212 per share. &nbsp;A copy of the 
convertible promissory note is attached as an exhibit to this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">At the meeting 
of the board of directors of the registrant held on September 25, 2015, the 
board of directors voted that any new director elected to the board of directors
of the registrant shall receive $25,000 per year in shares of our common stock 
registered pursuant to a registration statement on Form S-8 filed with the SEC 
to be paid quarterly. &nbsp;In addition, any new director shall be required to 
make a direct investment of not less than $100,000 into the registrant in 
exchange for a convertible promissory note to be submitted to the board of 
directors for approval.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">&nbsp;</P>

<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:18pt; text-indent:-18pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:18pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-size:8pt">(1)</P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin:0pt; padding-left:18pt; font-size:8pt">Unless
otherwise indicated, the address for each of these stockholders is c/o <FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">Bravo Multinational</FONT> Incorporated., 590 York Road, 
Unit 3, Niagara On The Lake, Ontario, CANADA L0S 1J0. Also, unless otherwise 
indicated, each person named in the table above has the sole voting and 
investment power with respect to our shares of common stock or preferred stock 
which he beneficially owns.</P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:18pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-size:8pt">(2)</P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin:0pt; padding-left:18pt; font-
size:8pt">Beneficial ownership is determined in accordance with the rules of the
Securities and Exchange Commission. &nbsp;As of February 29, 2016, there were 
outstanding 263,405,812 shares of our common stock. &nbsp;As of November 30, 
2015, we have 3,000,000 shares of the Series A Preferred Stock issued and 
outstanding. &nbsp;Each share of the Series A Preferred Stock has voting rights 
equal to 100 shares of our common stock. &nbsp;Further, each share of the Series
A Preferred Stock may be converted into 10 shares of our common stock. 
&nbsp;However, there are restrictions on the conversion rights of the Series A 
Preferred Stock as stated elsewhere in this report. In addition,<FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman"> Mr. Frydman has assigned to Mr. Martin Wolfe all of his 
voting rights with respect of our Series A Preferred Stock. </FONT> &nbsp;See 
&#147;Item 5. &nbsp;Market for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity, Related 
Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities.&#148; &nbsp;Taken
together, the holders of the Series A Preferred Stock have voting rights equal 
to 300,000,000 shares of our common stock, which number exceeds our outstanding 
shares of common stock on February 29, 2016. &nbsp;As of February 29, 2016, none
of the Series A Preferred Stock has been converted into shares of our common 
stock. &nbsp;As a result of their ownership (and voting right of our Series A 
Preferred Stock in the case of Mr. Wolfe, which were assigned by Mr. Frydman to 
Mr. Wolfe) of 3,000,000 shares of our Series A Preferred Stock and 87,116,985 
&nbsp;in the aggregate, Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Kaiser, Kosta, and Frydman 
have voting control over 387,116,985 shares of our common stock, which number 
exceeds our outstanding shares of common stock on February 29, 2016. &nbsp;If 
you include the shares of our common stock owned by Douglas Brooks, Messrs. 
Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, Kaiser, Kosta, and Frydman have voting control over 
393,608,600 &nbsp;shares of our common stock, which number exceeds our 
outstanding shares of common stock on February 29, 2016. &nbsp;Therefore, 
Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, Kaiser, Kosta, and Frydman, as a group, have 
voting control over all matters which may be acted upon by our stockholders. 
&nbsp;There are no voting agreements among Messrs. Parliament, Wolfe, Brooks, 
Kaiser, Kosta, and Frydman, other than the assignment by Mr. Frydman to Mr. 
Wolfe of all voting rights possessed by Mr. Frydman in his 250,000 shares of 
Series A Preferred. </P>

Mrs. Pierre Quilliam, footnotes (14), (15), and (16), in the past all of the 
shares described in the referenced footnotes have been voted as dictated by 
Pierre Quilliam. &nbsp;Consequently, we regard the owners of the shares 
described in footnotes (14), (15), and (16) as affiliates of Pierre Quilliam. 
&nbsp;Therefore, taken together, the shares described in the referenced 
footnotes along with the shares described in footnotes (12), (18), (19), (20), 
(21), (22), and (23), provide Pierre Quilliam with voting control over 
58,983,630 shares of our common stock, which number represents 22.76% of our 
outstanding shares of common stock.</P>

<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>37</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">As a result of 
the common stock and preferred stock ownership by Messrs. Parliament, Brooks, 
Wolfe, Kaiser, Kosta, and Frydman, they will be able to control all matters 
requiring stockholder approval including the election of directors, merger or 
consolidation. &nbsp;This concentration of ownership may delay, deter or prevent
acts which could reduce the market price of our common stock.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Other than as 
stated herein, there are no arrangements or understandings, known to us, 
including any pledge by any person of our securities:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-
36pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">The operation of which may at a subsequent date result in
a change in control of the registrant; or</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:36pt; text-indent:-
36pt; font-family:Symbol"><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:36pt"><FONT 
FACE="Times New Roman">With respect to the election of directors or other 
matters.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt; page-break-before:always"><B>Item 13. </B><B>Certain Relationships and 
Related Transactions and Director Independence.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt">Other as 
stated above, there are no other agreements with any of our officers and 
directors.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:37.45pt">Richard 
Kaiser jointly owns Yes International which is under contract with the 
registrant to provide Investor Relations, Consulting, Press Services and Edgar 
Filing services. &nbsp;Yes International signed a one year contract in October 
2014, and received $3,500 in combination of cash and/or restricted shares of our
common stock, issued pursuant to a registration statement on Form S-8 under the 
Securities Act. &nbsp;This agreement was cancelled as of March 24, 2015.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:54pt; text-indent:-
54pt"><B>Item 14. </B><B>Principal Accounting Fees and Services.</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Audit Fees</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The aggregate 
fees billed by Scrudato &amp; Co. CPA for professional services rendered for the
audit of our annual financial statements for the fiscal year ended December 31, 
2015, were $14,000 and December 31, 2014 $14,000.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Audit Related Fees</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The aggregate 
audit-related fees billed by Scrudato &amp; Co. CPA for professional services 
rendered for the audit of our annual financial statements for the fiscal year 
ended December 31, 2015, were $14,000 and December 31, 2014 were $14,000</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>Tax Fees</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">The aggregate 
tax fees billed by Scrudato &amp; Co. CPA for professional services rendered for
tax services for the fiscal years ended December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014,
were NIL.</P>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center>38</P>
<P style="margin:0pt">
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-
before:always">&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><B>All Other Fees</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">There were no 
other fees billed by Scrudato &amp; Co. CPA for professional services rendered 
during the fiscal years ended December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014 other than
as stated under the captions Audit Fees, Audit-Related Fees, and Tax Fees.</P>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

54pt"><B>Item 15.</B></P>

Financial Statement Schedules.</B></P>

36pt">(a)</P>

statements are included in Item 8 of this report.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-left:72pt; text-indent:-
36pt">(b)</P>

exhibits contained in this report are included in Item 8 of this report.</P>

  <BR>
  <BR>
</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>F1</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC 
ACCOUNTING FIRM</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:30pt; padding-
right:30pt" align=justify>Scrudato &amp; Co., PA</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:1.65pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:30.25pt; padding-right:30.25pt" align=justify>Certified Public Accounting 
Firm</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:1.65pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:30.25pt; padding-right:30.25pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:13.7pt" align=justify><B>To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of 
</B><B>BRAVO MULTINATIONAL CORPORATION FORMERLY &nbsp;GOLDLAND HOLDINGS 
CO.</B></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:13.7pt" align=justify>We have audited the accompanying balance sheet of 
Bravo Multinational Corporation formerly Goldland Holdings Co. as of December
31, 2015 and December 31, 2014 and the related consolidated statements of 
operations, changes in stockholders' equity and cash flows for the year then 
ended. These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company 
management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial 
statements based on our audit.</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:13.7pt" align=justify>We conducted our audit in accordance with the 
standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). 
Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable
assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of 
material misstatement. The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged 
to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting. Our 
audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a 
basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, 
but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the 
Company's internal control over financial reporting. Accordingly, we express no 
such opinion. An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence 
supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements,
assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by 
management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. 
We believe that our audit provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:13.7pt" align=justify>In our opinion, the financial statements referred to 
above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Bravo 
Multinational Corporation formerly Goldland Holdings Co. at December 31, 2015 
and December 31, 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows 
for the year then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally 
accepted in the United States of America.</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-
left:13.7pt" align=justify>The accompanying financial statements have been 
prepared assuming that the Company will continue as a going concern. As 
discussed in Note 11, the Company has incurred significant accumulated deficits,
recurring operating losses and a negative working capital. This and other 
factors raise substantial doubt about the Company's ability to continue as a 
going concern. Management's plans in regard to these matters are also discussed 
in Note 11. The financial statements do not include any adjustments that might 
result from the outcome of this uncertainty.</P>
<P style="margin-top:15pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:13.5pt" 
align=justify>/s/ John Scrudato CPA</P>
<P style="margin-top:7.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:13.5pt" 
align=justify>Califon, New Jersey</P>
<P style="margin-top:2.5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:13.5pt" 
align=justify>April 13, 2016</P>
<P style="margin-top:25pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:pt; padding-
bottom:3pt; border-bottom:0.pt solid #000000" align=center>7 Valley View Drive 
Califon, New Jersey 07830</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-left:pt; padding-right:-
13.5pt" align=center>Registered Public Company Accounting Oversight Board 
Firm</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify><BR>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>F-4</P>

<P style="margin:0pt; page-break-before:always" align=center><B>BRAVO 
MULTINATIONAL CORPORATION</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center><b>STATEMENTS OF 
STOCKHOLDERS' DEFICIT</b></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center><b>FOR THE YEARS ENDED
DECEMBER 31, 2015 &amp; 2014</b><BR>

<div align="center">
  <TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0>
    <TR><TD width=174></TD><TD width=111></TD><TD width=103></TD><TD 
width=109></TD><TD width=115></TD><TD width=122></TD><TD width=102></TD><TD

<P style="line-height:8pt; margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt" 
align=center>SEE ACCOMPANYING NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>F-6</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; page-break-before:always" align=center><B>BRAVO 
MULTINATIONAL CORPORATION</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center><b>NOTES TO FINANCIAL 
STATEMENTS</b></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center><B>DECEMBER 31, 2015 
&amp; 2014</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:20pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 1: 
ORGANIZATION &amp; DESCRIPTION OF BUSINESS</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:20pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="line-height:12.8pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-
indent:36pt">Bravo Multinational Corporation (the &#147;Company,&#148; 
&#147;we&#148; or &#147;us&#148;) was originally formed as Montrose Ventures, 
Inc. in the State of Delaware on May 25, 1989. On April 23, 1996, the 
Company&#146;s name was changed to Java Group, Inc., and on September 1, 2004 
the name was changed to Consolidated General Corp. &nbsp;On August 7, 2007, the 
company&#146;s name was changed to GoldCorp Holdings Co. On October 15, 2010, 
our name was changed to GoldLand Holdings Co. On April 6, 2016, we. changed our 
corporate name to Bravo Multinational Incorporated. &nbsp;On March 22, 2016, the
board of directors of the company, pursuant to Section 242 of the Delaware 
General Corporation Law, determined it was in the best interests of the company 
that the name of the company should be changed to Bravo Multinational 
Incorporated, with such change of name to be effective upon compliance with all 
regulatory requirements mandated by FINRA. &nbsp;Further, as a result of the 
change of the company&#146;s name and upon satisfaction of all regulatory 
requirements, the trading symbol for the shares of the compant&#146;s common 
stock should be changed to &#147;BRVO,&#148; and the company&#146;s CUSIP 
identifier be changed to a newly issued number. &nbsp;FINRA granted its approval
of the change of the company&#146;s name on April 6, 2015. &nbsp;As a result of 
the change of name of thecompany, the company&#146;s trading symbol was changed 
to &#147;BRVO&#148; and the CUSIP identifier was changed to 10568F109.</P>
<P style="line-height:12.8pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-
indent:36pt">The company filed a Form 8-K with the SEC on April 7, 2016, 
announcing the change of name, trading symbol, and CUSIP identifier.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company owns land
and lease claims on War Eagle Mountain in the state of Idaho. &nbsp;The Company 
has entered into a lease agreement with Silver Falcon Mining, Inc. (&#147;Silver
Falcon&#148;) under which Silver Falcon is entitled to mine the land and the 
Company is entitled to a 15% net royalty on all minerals extracted by Silver 
Falcon from tailing piles on the premises or through shafts or adits located on 
the premises.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>On September 19, 
2013, our wholly-owned subsidiary entered into an asset purchase agreement to 
acquire certain gaming equipment from Universal Entertainment SAS, Ltd., a 
corporation formed under the laws of the Country of Colombia, for 17,450,513 
shares of our common stock (post-split). Closing was conditioned on our 
completion of a 1 for 10 reverse stock split, among other things. The equipment 
includes approximately 67 video poker and slot machines; 8 blackjack and 
miscellaneous game tables and related furniture and equipment; roulette table 
and related furniture and equipment; bingo equipment and furniture; casino 
chips, bill acceptors, coin counter and related equipment; and miscellaneous 
office equipment, like chairs, tables, etc. We completed the reverse split in
March 2014, and completed the purchase on March 6, 2014. Upon closing of the 
acquisition, we simultaneously leased the equipment to VOMBLOM &amp; POMARE 
S.A., a company formed under the laws of Colombia, which provides for lease 
payments of $700,000 per year, payable $58,333 per month, and a term of five 
years with one five year renewal option. This lease was subsequently 
suspended.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp; </P><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 2:SUMMARY 
OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Revenue 
Recognition</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>Revenue is 
recognized when earned according to lease and royalty agreements. Lease income 
is recognized as earned on a monthly basis according to the terms of the lease. 
Royalty income is recognized as ore is extracted and refined.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Cash and Cash 
Equivalents</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>Cash and cash 
equivalents consist of all cash balances and highly liquid investments with an 
original maturity of three months or less. Because of the short maturity of 
these investments, the carrying amounts approximate their fair value. </P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Facilities and 
equipment</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>
  Expenditures for new facilities or equipment and expenditures that extend the 
useful lives of existing facilities or equipment are capitalized and recorded at
cost. The facilities and equipment are depreciated using the straight-line 
method at rates sufficient to depreciate such costs over the estimated 
productive lives, which do not exceed the related estimated mine lives, of such 
facilities based on proven and probable reserves.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:6.65pt"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:6.65pt" align=center>F-7</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Impairment of 
Long-Lived Assets</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company 
reviews and evaluates its long-lived assets for impairment when events or 
changes in circumstances indicate that the related carrying amounts may not be 
recoverable.</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>An impairment is 
considered to exist if the total estimated future cash flows on an undiscounted 
basis are less than the carrying amount of the assets, including goodwill, if 
any.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>An impairment loss is
measured and recorded based on discounted estimated future cash flows. Future 
cash flows are estimated based on quantities of recoverable minerals, expected 
gold and other commodity prices (considering current and historical prices, 
price trends and related factors), production levels and operating costs of 
production and capital, all based on life-of-mine plans. Existing proven and 
probable reserves and value beyond proven and probable reserves, including 
mineralization other than proven and probable reserves and other material that 
is not part of the measured, indicated or inferred resource base, are included 
when determining the fair value of mine site reporting units at acquisition and,
subsequently, in determining whether the assets are impaired. The term 
&#147;recoverable minerals&#148; refers to the estimated amount of gold or other
commodities that will be obtained after taking into account losses during ore 
processing and treatment. Estimates of recoverable minerals from such 
exploration stage mineral interests are risk adjusted based on management&#146;s
relative confidence in such materials. In estimating future cash flows, assets 
are grouped at the lowest level for which there are identifiable cash flows that
are largely independent of future cash flows from other asset groups. The 
Company&#146;s estimates of future cash flows are based on numerous assumptions 
and it is possible that actual future cash flows will be significantly different
than the estimates, as actual future quantities of recoverable minerals, gold 
and other commodity prices, production levels and operating costs of production 
and capital are each subject to significant risks and uncertainties.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" 
align=justify><B><I>Goodwill</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company 
evaluates, on at least an annual basis during the fourth quarter, the carrying 
amount of goodwill to determine whether current events and circumstances 
indicate that such carrying amount may no longer be recoverable. To accomplish 
this, the Company compares the estimated fair value of its reporting units to 
their carrying amounts. If the carrying value of a reporting unit exceeds its 
estimated fair value, the Company compares the implied fair value of the 
reporting unit&#146;s goodwill to its carrying amount, and any excess of the 
carrying value over the fair value is charged to earnings. The Company&#146;s 
fair value estimates are based on numerous assumptions and it is possible that 
actual fair value will be significantly different than the estimates, as actual 
future quantities of recoverable minerals, gold and other commodity prices, 
production levels and operating costs of production and capital are each subject
to significant risks and uncertainties.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Stock Based 
Compensation</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company has 
issued and may issue stock in lieu of cash for certain transactions. The fair 
value of the stock, which is based on comparable cash purchases, third party 
quotations, or the value of services, whichever is more readily determinable, is
used to value the transaction</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Use of 
Estimates</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:6.65pt" align=justify>The Company&#146;s
Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America. The preparation of the 
Company&#146;s Financial Statements requires the Company to make estimates and 
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the 
related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the 
Financial Statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during 
the reporting period. The Company bases its estimates on historical experience 
and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the 
circumstances. Accordingly, actual results may differ significantly from these 
estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
<BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:6.65pt" align=center>F-8</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Basic and 
Diluted Per Common Share</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>Basic earnings per 
common share is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by 
the weighted average number of common shares assumed to be outstanding during 
the period of computation. Diluted earnings per share is computed similar to 
basic earnings per share except that the denominator is increased to include the
number of additional common shares that would have been outstanding if the 
potential common shares had been issued and if the additional common shares were
dilutive. Because we have incurred net losses, basic and diluted loss per share 
are the same since additional potential common shares would be anti-
dilutive.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Research and 
Development</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company expenses 
research and development costs as incurred.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B><I>Significant 
Recent Accounting Pronouncements</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>In July 2013, ASC 
guidance was issued related to the presentation of an unrecognized tax benefit 
when a net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss or a tax credit 
carryforward exists. The updated guidance requires an entity to net its 
unrecognized tax benefits against the deferred tax assets for all same
jurisdiction net operating loss carryforward, a similar tax loss, or tax credit 
carryforwards. A gross presentation will be required only if such carryforwards 
are not available or would not be used by the entity to settle any additional 
income taxes resulting from disallowance of the uncertain tax position. The 
update is effective prospectively for the Company&#146;s fiscal year beginning 
January&nbsp;1, 2014. The Company is still evaluating the impact of the updated 
guidance on the consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash 
flows. </P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 3:NOTES 
PAYABLE</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The notes payable 
are due to various entities and bear interest at rates from 0 to 14%</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>

<P align="left" style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt"><BR>
</P>
<P align="center" style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt">F-9</P>
<P align="center" style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P align="center" style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt">&nbsp;</P>
<P align="left" style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt">Deferred income tax 
assets and the related valuation allowances result principally from the 
potential tax benefits of net operating loss carryforwards.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=justify>The Company has 
recorded a valuation allowance to reflect the uncertainty of the ultimate 
utilization of the deferred tax assets as follows:</P>

<P style="margin:0pt" align=justify>For financial statement purposes, no tax 
benefit has been reported as the Company has had significant losses in recent 
years and realization of the tax benefits is uncertain. Accordingly, a valuation
allowance has been established in the full amount of the deferred tax asset.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt" align=justify>At December 31, 
2015, the Company had net operating loss carryforwards of approximately 
24,125,219 which will be available to offset future taxable income. These net 
operating loss carryforwards expire at various times through </P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=justify>2033. The utilization of the net operating loss carryforwards is 
dependent upon the Company&#146;s ability to generate sufficient taxable income 
during the carryforward period.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 5:RELATED 
PARTY TRANSACTIONS</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><I>Lease Transactions
with Silver Falcon</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>On October 11, 2007, 
we entered into a lease agreement with Silver Falcon, under which we leased our 
owned and leased acreage on War Eagle Mountain, Idaho to Silver Falcon. 
&nbsp;Silver Falcon is responsible for all mining activities on our land, and we
are entitled to annual lease payments of $1,000,000 per year payable monthly, a 
non accountable expense allowance of $10,000 per month for any month in which 
ore is mined from our property, and a net royalty of 15% from any proceeds 
payable to Silver Falcon by the refiner of ore produced from tailing piles on 
the premises or through shafts or adits located on the premises. &nbsp;The lease
initially provided that lease payments must commence April 1, 2008. 
&nbsp;Because Silver Falcon has been unable to commence operations according to 
its original schedule, we have agreed to extend the commencement date several 
times, to January 1, 2012. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>In the first quarter 
of 2011, we amended the above-described lease with Silver Falcon. &nbsp;The 
amendment provided that the annual lease payments would be deferred for a 
fifteen-month period from October 2010 to December 2011, and the term of the 
Lease would be extended for an equal amount of time. Silver Falcon remains 
remain obligated to pay any royalties or the non-accountable fee that accrues 
during the deferral period. &nbsp;Several of our officers and directors were 
also officers and directors of Silver Falcon. It is the intention of the company
to enforce collection of all amounts owing under the lease, however, due to the 
uncertainty of collection, no amounts have been included in the current 
year&#146;s financial statements. As at November 30, 2015 there were no common 
officers or directors between the two companies</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><I>Loan Transactions 
with Silver Falcon</I></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>From time to time, we
have borrowed money from Silver Falcon, and Silver Falcon has borrowed money 
from us. &nbsp;All amounts have been written off. </P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center>F-10</P>
<br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 
6:COMMITMENTS &amp; CONTINGENCIES</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><B>No 
Contingencies</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>In August 2010, 
Richard Corrigan, acting as a debtor in possession in his personal bankruptcy 
case, filed an adversary proceeding against us to recover amounts due under a 
consulting agreement dated July 1, 2009.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The consulting 
agreement provided that Mr. Corrigan would provide certain consulting, mapping 
and assaying services on three lode claims owned by us on War Eagle 
Mountain.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The consulting 
agreement provided that Mr. Corrigan&#146;s compensation would be a bonus of 
150,000 shares of common stock, valued by mutual agreement at approximately 
$150,000, and monthly consulting payments of $5,000 per month. The consulting 
agreement also provided that Mr. Corrigan was entitled to monthly transportation
expenses of $250 per month. We terminated Mr. Corrigan on December 8, 2009 for 
non-performance. &nbsp;In 2011, Mr. Corrigan&#146;s filed a Chapter 7 case. In 
November 2011, Mr. Corrigan&#146;s bankruptcy trustee filed an amended complaint
in the adversary proceeding, in which Chapter 7 trustee seeks recovery of the 
alleged $150,000 bonus and the balance of the unpaid consulting fees and travel 
expense allowance of $60,900, for a total of $210,900, plus interest and 
attorney&#146;s fees. On June 19, 2013, the Company learned that the District 
Court for the Third Judicial District of the State of Idaho for the County of 
Owyhee entered a default judgment against the Company in the case.&nbsp;The 
default judgment grants a judgment against the Company in the amount of 
$284,449. &nbsp;The Company retained new counsel who filed a motion to vacate 
the default judgment. &nbsp;On September 19, 2013, the court entered a 
memorandum opinion setting aside the default judgment. &nbsp;. &nbsp;On 
September 15, 2014, the court ordered the payment of 150,000 shares of our 
common shares to Mr. Corrigan to conclude the matter. &nbsp;We issued the shares
on January 13, 2015.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 7:CAPITAL 
STOCK</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>At December 31, 2015,
the Company's authorized capital stock was 1,00000,000,000 shares of Common 
Stock, par value $0.0001 per share, and 5,000,000 shares of Preferred Stock, par
value $0.0001 per share. &nbsp;On that date, the Company had outstanding 
263,405,812 shares of Common Stock, and 3,000,000 shares of Preferred Stock. 
</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>On March 6, 2014, the
company amended its Certificate of Incorporation to increase its authorized 
capital stock to 1,000,000,000 shares of Common Stock, par value $0.0001 per 
share. &nbsp;In addition, the company amended it Certificate of Incorporation to
effect a reverse split of its common stock at a ratio of one share for each ten 
shares.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>

<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 8: REVERSE 
STOCK SPLIT</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>On March 6, 2014, the
Company amended it Certificate of Incorporation to increase its authorized 
capital stock to 1,000,000,000 shares of Common Stock, par value $0.0001 per 
share. In addition, the Company amended it Certificate of Incorporation to 
effect a reverse split of its common stock at a ratio of one share for each ten 
shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 9: 
EQUIPMENT ACQUISITION</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>On September 19, 
2013, the Company (through its wholly-owned subsidiary, Universal Entertainment 
SAS, Inc.) entered into an Asset Purchase Agreement with Universal Entertainment
SAS, Ltd., a corporation formed under the laws of the Country of Colombia, to 
acquire certain casino equipment (the &#147;<I>Equipment</I>&#148;)(such 
transaction hereinafter referred to as the &#147;<I>Equipment 
Acquisition</I>&#148;). Closing of the Equipment Acquisition was conditioned on 
the Company effecting a one for ten reverse stock split, among other conditions.
The Equipment had an original cost of $874,970, and includes approximately 67 
video poker and slot machines; 8 blackjack and miscellaneous game tables and 
related furniture and equipment; roulette table and related furniture and 
equipment; bingo equipment and furniture; casino chips, bill acceptors, coin 
counter and related equipment; and miscellaneous office equipment, like chairs, 
tables, etc. The equipment was located at several establishments. The Asset 
Purchase Agreement provides that at closing of the Equipment Acquisition the 
Company the following transactions would take place:</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center>F-13</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:7.35pt"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt; page-break-
before:always" align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company issued 17,450,535 shares of Common Stock to acquire the 
Equipment.</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company would entered into a lease (the &#147;Lease&#148;) of the 
Equipment to VOMBLOM &amp; POMARE S.A., a company formed under the laws of 
Colombia, which provides for lease payments of $700,000 per year, payable 
$58,333 per month, and a term of five years with one five year renewal option. 
The lease was subsequently suspended due to lack of specific performance by all 
parties.</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company would enter into consulting agreements with two shareholders 
of the seller, which provide for aggregate annual compensation of $370,000 per 
year payable in restricted shares of the Company&#146;s common stock, and have a
term of five years. </FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company entered into certain employment or consulting agreements 
which will obligate the Company to make total payments of $1,235,000 per year 
for five years, which payments will be made in shares of the Company&#146;s 
Common Stock at its market price at the time of issuance.</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company would issue 19,977,980 shares of the Company&#146;s Common 
Stock to certain officers, directors, and consultants, as well as the two 
principals of Universal Entertainment SAS, Ltd., as bonuses under consulting 
agreements or employment agreements with such persons.</FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company would issue 17,000,000 shares of the Company&#146;s Common 
Stock to certain officers, directors and significant shareholders. </FONT></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-10pt; padding-
left:36pt; text-indent:-18pt; font-family:Symbol; font-size:8pt" 
align=justify><FONT FACE="Symbol">&#183;</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:36pt" align=justify><FONT FACE="Times New 
Roman">The Company would cancel 8,600,000 options held by certain officers and 
directors of the Company.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company accrued 
the value of the shares issuable as bonuses at closing of the Equipment 
Acquisition as a current liability at December 31, 2013. &nbsp;The Company 
completed the Equipment Acquisition and related transactions in March 2014. 
&nbsp;(See <I>Note 12 &#150; Subsequent Events</I>). &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify><B>NOTE 10:GOING 
CONCERN</B></P><br><br>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>These financial 
statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting
principles applicable to a going concern, which contemplates the realization of 
assets and the satisfaction of liabilities and commitments in the normal course 
of business. &nbsp;However, the Company has incurred net losses of ($7,019,876) 
and ($2,943,120) for the twelve months ended December 31, 2014 and 2015, 
respectively.</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>The Company has 
remained in business primarily through deferral of salaries by management, loans
from the Company&#146;s chief executive officer, and loans from a significant 
shareholder. The Company intends on financing its future development activities 
from the same sources, until such time that funds provided by operations are 
sufficient to fund working capital requirements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=justify>These factors, among 
others, raise substantial doubt about the Company&#146;s ability to continue as 
a going concern for a reasonable period of time.</P>
<P style="margin-top:3.35pt; margin-bottom:-12pt" align=justify>&nbsp;</P><br>

<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=left><B>Exhibit 31.1</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>AMENDED 
CERTIFICATION OF CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER<BR>
AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO SECTION 302 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">I, Paul 
Parliament, certify that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">1.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">I have reviewed 
this Form 10-K/A, of Bravo Multinational Incorporated;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">2.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Based on my 
knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact 
or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light
of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with
respect to the period covered by this report;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">3.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Based on my 
knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in
this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, 
results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the 
periods present in this report;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">4.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The 
registrant&#146;s other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for 
establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in 
Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial 
reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13-a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the 
registrant and have:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(a)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Designed such 
disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and 
procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material 
information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries,
is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the 
period in which this report is being prepared;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(b)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Designed such 
internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over 
financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable 
assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation 
of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principals;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(c)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Evaluated the 
effectiveness of the registrant&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures and 
presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the 
disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this 
report based on such evaluation; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(d)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Disclosed in 
this report any change in the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial 
reporting that occurred during the registrant&#146;s most recent fiscal quarter 
(the registrant&#146;s fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) 
that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the 
registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">5.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The 
registrant&#146;s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our
most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the 
registrant&#146;s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant&#146;s 
board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(a)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">All significant 
deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal 
control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect
the registrant&#146;s ability to record, process, summarize and Report financial
information; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(b)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Any fraud, 
whether or not material, that involved management or other employees who have a 
significant role in the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial 
reporting.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Date: April 27, 
2016.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-
left:234pt"><U>&nbsp;&nbsp;/s/ Paul Parliament<BR>
</U></P><br>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:0pt; text-
indent:234pt">Paul Parliament, President and Chief Executive Officer</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=left>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=left>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=left>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; page-break-before:always" 
align=left><B>Exhibit 31.2</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>AMENDED 
CERTIFICATION OF CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER<BR>
AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO SECTION 302 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">I, Martin Wolfe,
certify that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">1.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">I have reviewed 
this Form 10-K/A, of Bravo Multinational Incorporated;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">2.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Based on my 
knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact 
or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light
of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with 
respect to the period covered by this report;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">3.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Based on my 
knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in
this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, 
results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the 
periods present in this report;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">4.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The 
registrant&#146;s other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for 
establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in 
Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial 
reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13-a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the 
registrant and have:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(a)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Designed such 
disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and 
procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material 
information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries,
is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the 
period in which this report is being prepared;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(b)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Designed such 
internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over 
financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable 
assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation 
of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally 
accepted accounting principals;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(c)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Evaluated the 
effectiveness of the registrant&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures and 
presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the 
disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this 
report based on such evaluation; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(d)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Disclosed in 
this report any change in the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial 
reporting that occurred during the registrant&#146;s most recent fiscal quarter 
(the registrant&#146;s fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) 
that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the 
registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">5.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The 
registrant&#146;s other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our
most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the 
registrant&#146;s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant&#146;s 
board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(a)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">All significant 
deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal 
control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect
the registrant&#146;s ability to record, process, summarize and Report financial
information; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:72pt">(b)</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:90pt">Any fraud, 
whether or not material, that involved management or other employees who have a 
significant role in the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial 
reporting.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Date: April 27, 
2016.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-
left:234pt"><U>&nbsp;&nbsp;/s/ Martin Wolfe<BR>
</U></P><br>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; padding-left:pt; text-
indent:234pt">Martin Wolfe, Chief Financial Officer and Principal Accounting 
Officer</P>

align=left><B>Exhibit 32.1</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>AMENDED CERTIFICATION OF CHIEF EXECUTIVE 
OFFICER<BR>
PURSUANT TO 18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>SECTION 906 OF THE
SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In connection 
with the accompanying Amended Annual Report on Form 10-K/A of &nbsp;Bravo 
Multinational Incorporated for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2015, I, Paul
Parliament, Chief Executive Officer of &nbsp;Bravo Multinational Incorporated, 
hereby certify pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to 
Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, to the best of my knowledge and 
belief, that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">1.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Such Amended 
Annual Report on Form 10-K/A for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2015, fully
complies with the requirements of section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities 
Exchange Act of 1934; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">2.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The information 
contained in such Amended Annual Report on Form 10-K/A for the fiscal year 
ending December 31, 2015, fairly presents, in all material respects, the 
financial condition and results of operations of &nbsp;Bravo Multinational 
Incorporated.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Date: April 27, 
2016.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-
left:234pt"><U>&nbsp;&nbsp;/s/ Paul Parliament<BR>
</U></P><br>
<P style="margin:0pt; padding-left:t; text-indent:234pt">Paul Parliament, 
President and Chief Executive Officer</P>

align=left><B>Exhibit 32.2</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>AMENDED CERTIFICATION OF CHIEF FINANCIAL 
OFFICER<BR>
PURSUANT TO 18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>SECTION 906 OF THE
SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">In connection 
with the accompanying Amended Annual Report on Form 10-K/A of &nbsp;Bravo 
Multinational Incorporated for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2015, I, 
Martin Wolfe, Chief Financial Officer and Principal Accounting Officer of 
&nbsp;Bravo Multinational Incorporated, hereby certify pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 
Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 
2002, to the best of my knowledge and belief, that:</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">1.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">Such Amended 
Annual Report on Form 10-K/A for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2015, fully
complies with the requirements of section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities 
Exchange Act of 1934; and</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; text-indent:36pt">2.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:54pt">The information 
contained in such Amended Annual Report on Form 10-K/A for the fiscal year 
ending December 31, 2015, fairly presents, in all material respects, the 
financial condition and results of operations of &nbsp;Bravo Multinational 
Incorporated.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt; text-indent:36pt">Date: April 27, 
2016</P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:-12pt; padding-

<P align="center" style="margin:0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt;"><BR>
<B>BRAVO MULTINATIONAL INCORPORATED</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt" align=center><B>Proxy for Annual 
Meeting of Stockholders </B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:10pt" align=center><B>To Be Held on 
September 29, 2016</B></P>
<P style="margin:0pt" align=center><B>THIS PROXY IS SOLICITED ON BEHALF OF THE 
BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF THE COMPANY </B></P>
<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:24.5pt">The 
undersigned, revoking all prior proxies, hereby appoint(s) Paul Parliament and 
Douglas Brooks, and each of them, with full power of substitution, as proxies to
represent and vote, as designated herein, all shares of Common Stock of Bravo 
Multinational Incorporated (the &#147;Company&#148;) which the undersigned would
be entitled to vote if personally present at the 2016 Annual Meeting of 
Stockholders of the Company to be held at 11:00 a.m., Eastern Time, on September
29, 2016, at 30 North Park Road, Thornhill, Ontario, CANADA, and at any 
adjournment thereof.</P>
<P style="margin-top:10pt; margin-bottom:0pt; text-indent:24.5pt"><B>In their 
discretion, the proxies are authorized to vote upon such other matters as may 
properly come before the meeting or any adjournment thereof.</B></P>
